P3para.Text: make arrangements about the carrying out of ASB case reviews by those bodies (“review procedures”); and
ensure that the current review procedures are published.

P2para.Text: The review procedures must include provision about the making of applications for ASB case reviews; and, in particular, must—

P3para.Text: specify the point of contact for making applications, and
ensure that applications made to that point of contact are passed on to all the relevant bodies in the local government area.

P2para.Text: In a situation where—

P3para.Text: an application for an ASB case review is made, and

at least three (or, if a different number is specified in the review procedures, at least that number of) qualifying complaints have been made about the anti-social behaviour to which the application relates,

P2para.Text: the relevant bodies must decide that the threshold for a review is met.

In any other situation where an application for an ASB case review is made, the question whether the threshold for a review is met must be decided by the relevant bodies in accordance with the review procedures; and the procedures may, in particular, include provision for this purpose which is framed by reference to any of these matters—

P3para.Text: the persistence of the anti-social behaviour about which the original complaint was made;
the harm caused, or the potential for harm to be caused, by that behaviour;
the adequacy of the response to that behaviour.

P2para.Text: After the relevant bodies have decided whether or not the threshold for a review is met, they must inform the applicant of their decision.

The relevant bodies who carry out an ASB case review may make recommendations to a person who exercises public functions (including recommendations to a relevant body) in respect of any matters arising from the review; and the person must have regard to the recommendations in exercising public functions.
The relevant bodies who carry out an ASB case review must inform the applicant of—

P3para.Text: the outcome of the review, and
any recommendations made in accordance with subsection (7).

P2para.Text: As soon as practicable after the end of a reporting period, the relevant bodies in a local government area must publish information about the following matters which relates to that period—

P3para.Text: the number of applications for ASB case reviews made to those bodies;
the number of times those bodies decided that the threshold for a review was not met;
the number of ASB case reviews those bodies have carried out;
the number of ASB case reviews carried out by those bodies that have resulted in recommendations being made.

P2para.Text: The question whether a complaint made about anti-social behaviour is a “qualifying complaint” for the purposes of subsection (4) is to be determined in accordance with subsections (11) and (12).
A complaint about anti-social behaviour is a qualifying complaint if—

P3para.Text: the complaint is made within the period of one month (or, if a different period is specified in the review procedures, that period) beginning with the date on which the behaviour is alleged to have occurred; and

the application for the ASB case review is made within the period of six months (or, if a different period is specified in the review procedures, that period) beginning with the date on which the complaint is made.

P2para.Text: But where a person makes two or more complaints about anti-social behaviour which meet the requirements in subsection (11), the question of which complaint is, or which complaints are, qualifying complaints is to be decided by the relevant bodies in accordance with the review procedures.

The procedures may, in particular, include provision for this purpose which is framed by reference to whether different complaints relate to different aspects of particular anti-social behaviour (including different incidents comprised in particular anti-social behaviour).

The procedures may, in particular, include provision for this purpose which is framed by reference to whether different complaints relate to different aspects of particular anti-social behaviour (including different incidents comprised in particular anti-social behaviour).
Schedule 4 (ASB case reviews: supplementary provision) has effect.
This section applies for the purposes of section 96, this section and Schedule 4.
In relation to England—

Para.Text: “local government area” means an area for which there is—
a relevant district council, or
a unitary authority;
“relevant district council” means the council of a district so far as it is not a unitary authority;
“unitary authority” means—
the council of a county so far as it is the council for an area for which there are no district councils,
the council of any district comprised in an area for which there is no county council,
a London borough council,
the Common Council of the City of London in its capacity as a local authority, or
the Council of the Isles of Scilly;

P2para.Text: and, in relation to a local government area in England—

Para.Text: “local provider of social housing” means a private registered provider of social housing that—
grants tenancies of dwelling-houses in that area, or
manages any house or other property in that area;
“relevant bodies” means—
the relevant district council or the unitary authority,
the chief officer of police for the police area which that local government area is within,
each clinical commissioning group established under section 14V of the National Health Service Act 2006 whose area is wholly or partly within that local government area, and
any local providers of social housing who are among the relevant bodies by virtue of the co-option arrangements made in relation to that local government area.

P2para.Text: In relation to Wales—

Para.Text: “local government area” means—
a county, or
a county borough;

P2para.Text: and, in relation to a local government area in Wales—

Para.Text: “local provider of social housing” means a body registered as a social landlord under section 3 of the Housing Act 1996 that—
grants tenancies of dwelling-houses in that area, or
manages any house or other property in that area;
“relevant bodies” means—
the council for the area,
the chief officer of police for the police area which that local government area is within,
each Local Health Board whose area is wholly or partly within that local government area, and
any local providers of social housing who are among the relevant bodies by virtue of the co-option arrangements made in relation to that local government area.

P2para.Text: These expressions have the meanings given—

Para.Text: “anti-social behaviour” means behaviour causing harassment, alarm or distress to members or any member of the public;
“applicant” means a person who makes an application for an ASB case review;
“ASB case review” has the meaning given in section 96(1);
“dwelling-house” has the same meaning as in the Housing Act 1985;
“co-option arrangements” has the meaning given in paragraph 5 of Schedule 4;
“reporting period”, in relation to the publication of information by the relevant bodies in a local government area, means a period, not exceeding 12 months, determined by those bodies.

P2para.Text: The Dangerous Dogs Act 1991 is amended as follows.
In section 3 (keeping dogs under proper control)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1)—

P4para.Text: for “a public place” there is substituted “any place in England or Wales (whether or not a public place)”;
after “injures any person” there is inserted “or assistance dog”;

P3para.Text: after subsection (1) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: A person (“D”) is not guilty of an offence under subsection (1) in a case which is a householder case.
For the purposes of subsection (1A) “a householder case” is a case where—

P3para.Text: the dog is dangerously out of control while in or partly in a building, or part of a building, that is a dwelling or is forces accommodation (or is both), and
at that time—

P4para.Text: the person in relation to whom the dog is dangerously out of control (“V”) is in, or is entering, the building or part as a trespasser, or
D (if present at that time) believed V to be in, or entering, the building or part as a trespasser.

P2para.Text: Section 76(8B) to (8F) of the Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008 (use of force at place of residence) apply for the purposes of this subsection as they apply for the purposes of subsection (8A) of that section (and for those purposes the reference in section 76(8D) to subsection (8A)(d) is to be read as if it were a reference to paragraph (b)(ii) of this subsection).

P3para.Text: subsection (3) is repealed;
in subsection (4)—

P4para.Text: the words “or (3)” are omitted;
for “either of those subsections” there is substituted “that subsection”;
in paragraph (b), for “two years” there is substituted “the relevant maximum specified in subsection (4A)”;

P3para.Text: after subsection (4) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (4)(b), the relevant maximum is—

P3para.Text: 14 years if a person dies as a result of being injured;
5 years in any other case where a person is injured;
3 years in any case where an assistance dog is injured (whether or not it dies).

P2para.Text: In section 4 (destruction and disqualification orders), the words “or (3)” are omitted in both places where they occur in subsection (1).
In section 4A (contingent destruction orders)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1)(a) the words “or (3)” are omitted;
in subsection (4) the words “or (3)” are omitted.

P2para.Text: In section 5 (seizure, entry of premises and evidence)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1)(c), for “one” there is substituted “a dog”;
after subsection (1) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: A constable or an officer of a local authority authorised by it to exercise the powers conferred by this subsection may seize any dog in a place in England or Wales which is not a public place, if the dog appears to the constable or officer to be dangerously out of control.
In section 10 (interpretation)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (2), after the definition of “advertisement” there is inserted—

Para.Text: “assistance dog” has the meaning given by section 173(1) of the Equality Act 2010;

P3para.Text: in subsection (3)—

P4para.Text: after “injure any person” there is inserted “or assistance dog”;
after “injuring a person” there is inserted “or assistance dog”.

P1group.Title: Whether a dog is a danger to public safety

P2para.Text: The Dangerous Dogs Act 1991 is amended as follows.
In section 1 (dogs bred for fighting) after subsection (6) there is inserted—
A scheme under subsection (3) or (5) may in particular include provision requiring a court to consider whether a person is a fit and proper person to be in charge of a dog.
In section 4 (destruction and disqualification orders) after subsection (1A)
there is inserted—
For the purposes of subsection (1A)(a), when deciding whether a dog would constitute a danger to public safety, the court—

P3para.Text: must consider—

P4para.Text: the temperament of the dog and its past behaviour, and
whether the owner of the dog, or the person for the time being in charge of it, is a fit and proper person to be in charge of the dog, and

P3para.Text: may consider any other relevant circumstances.

P2para.Text: Section 4B (destruction orders otherwise than on a conviction) is amended as follows—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), after “section 5(1) or (2) below” there is inserted “or in exercise of a power of seizure conferred by any other enactment”;
after subsection (2) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (2)(a), when deciding whether a dog would constitute a danger to public safety, the justice or sheriff—

P3para.Text: must consider—

P4para.Text: the temperament of the dog and its past behaviour, and
whether the owner of the dog, or the person for the time being in charge of it, is a fit and proper person to be in charge of the dog, and

P3para.Text: may consider any other relevant circumstances.

P1group.Title: Offence of possessing firearm for supply etc

P2para.Text: The Firearms Act 1968 is amended as set out in subsections (2) to (8).
In section 5 (which includes, in subsections (1) and (1A), offences of unauthorised possession etc of prohibited weapons and ammunition)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1) the words “, or manufactures, sells or transfers” are omitted;
in subsection (1A) the words “or sells or transfers” are omitted.

P2para.Text: After subsection (2) of that section there is inserted—
A person commits an offence if without authority—

P3para.Text: he manufactures any weapon or ammunition specified in subsection (1) of this section,
he sells or transfers any prohibited weapon or prohibited ammunition,
he has in his possession for sale or transfer any prohibited weapon or prohibited ammunition, or
he purchases or acquires for sale or transfer any prohibited weapon or prohibited ammunition.

P2para.Text: For subsection (3) of that section there is substituted—
In this section “authority” means an authority given in writing by—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State (in or as regards England and Wales), or
the Scottish Ministers (in or as regards Scotland).

P2para.Text: In section 5A (exemptions from requirement of authority under section 5)—

P3para.Text: in subsections (1), (3), (4), (5), (6) and (7), the words “subsection (1A) of” are omitted;
in subsections (1) and (3), for “any prohibited weapon or ammunition” there is substituted “any weapon, ammunition or missile specified in subsection (1A) of that section”.

P2para.Text: In section 51A (minimum sentences for certain offences), in subsection (1A), before paragraph (a) there is inserted—

P3para.Text: section 5(2A) (manufacture, sale or transfer of firearm, or possession etc for sale or transfer);

P2para.Text: In Schedule 6 (prosecution and punishment of offences), in Part 1 (table of punishments) the words “or distributing” are omitted in the entries for—

P3para.Text: section 5(1)(a), (ab), (aba), (ac), (ad), (ae), (af) or (c),
section 5(1)(b),
section 5(1A)(a), and
section 5(1A)(b), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g).

P2para.Text: In Part 1 of that Schedule, after the entry for section 5(1A)(b), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g) there is inserted—

tr.td: Manufacturing or distributing, or possessing for distribution, prohibited weapons or ammunition

P2para.Text: In section 1 of the Firearms (Amendment) Act 1997 (extension of section 5 of the 1968 Act to prohibit certain small firearms etc), after subsection (7) there is inserted—

In sections 2 to 7 below any reference to subsection (1)(aba) of section 5 of the 1968 Act shall include a reference to subsection (2A) of that section as it applies in relation to a firearm specified in subsection (1)(aba) of that section.

In section 8 below the reference to subsection (1)(aba), (b) or (c) of section 5 of the 1968 Act shall include a reference to subsection (2A) of that section as it applies in relation to any weapon or ammunition specified in subsection (1)(aba), (b) or (c) of that section.

P1group.Title: Functions of Scottish Ministers under Firearms Acts

P2para.Text: In section 5 of the Firearms Act 1968 (weapons subject to general prohibition)—

P3para.Text: in subsections (1) and (1A), for the words between “commits an offence if,” and “, he has in his possession” there is substituted “without authority”;

in subsection (4), for the words from the beginning to “the Scottish Ministers” there is substituted “An authority shall be subject to conditions specified in it, including such as the Secretary of State or the Scottish Ministers (as appropriate)”;
in subsection (6), for the words before “revoke an authority” there is substituted “The Secretary of State or the Scottish Ministers (as appropriate) may at any time, if they think fit,”.

P2para.Text: In section 5A of that Act (exemptions from requirement of authority under section 5)—

in subsection (6), for the words after “without the authority of the Secretary of State” there is substituted “or the Scottish Ministers (as appropriate)”.

P2para.Text: In the Firearms (Amendment) Act 1997—

P3para.Text: in sections 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7(1) and 8 (exemptions from prohibition on small firearms etc), for “The authority of the Secretary of State or the Scottish Ministers (by virtue of provision made under section 63 of the Scotland Act 1998)” there is substituted “The authority of the Secretary of State or the Scottish Ministers”;

in section 7(3), for the words “or the Scottish Ministers (by virtue of provision made under section 63 of the Scotland Act 1998)”, in the first place where they occur, there is substituted “or the Scottish Ministers”.

P2para.Text: In the Scotland Act 1998 (Transfer of Functions to the Scottish Ministers etc.) Order 1999 (S.I. 1999/1750)—

P3para.Text: in Schedule 1, in the entry for the Firearms Act 1968, the words “5 and” are omitted;
in Schedule 5, paragraph 3 and paragraph 18(2) to (6), (7)(a) and (8) are omitted.

P1group.Title: Possession of firearms by persons previously convicted of crime

P2para.Text: In section 21 of the Firearms Act 1968 (possession of firearms by persons previously convicted of crime), before subsection (3) there is inserted—
Where—

P3para.Text: a person has been sentenced to imprisonment for a term of three months or more, and
the sentence is suspended under section 189 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003,

P2para.Text: the person shall not have a firearm or ammunition in his possession at any time during the period of five years beginning with the second day after the date on which the sentence is passed.
In section 58(2) of that Act (saving for antique firearms), for “Nothing in this Act” there is substituted “Apart from—

P3para.Text: section 21 and Schedule 3, and
any other provision of this Act so far as it applies in relation to an offence under section 21,

P2para.Text: nothing in this Act
Where—

P3para.Text: a person is in possession of a firearm or ammunition immediately before the day on which subsection (1) comes into force,

by reason of a sentence imposed before that day, subsection (1) would (but for this subsection) make the person’s possession of the firearm or ammunition subject to a prohibition under section 21 of the Firearms Act 1968, and
the person’s possession of the firearm or ammunition immediately before that day is authorised by a certificate within the meaning given in section 57(4) of that Act,

P2para.Text: the prohibition does not apply while the certificate remains in force.

P1group.Title: Increased penalty for improper importation of firearms etc

In section 50 (penalty for improper importation of goods), in subsection (5A) (firearms and counterfeit currency etc), for the words after “shall have effect” there is substituted “as if for the words “imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years” there were substituted the words “imprisonment for life””.
In that section—

P3para.Text: in subsection (4), after “(5A),” there is inserted “(5AA),”;
at the end of paragraph (a) of subsection (5A) there is inserted “or”;
paragraph (c) of that subsection and the word “or” before it are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In the case of an offence under subsection (2) or (3) above committed in connection with the prohibition contained in section 20 of the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981, subsection (4)(b) above shall have effect as if for the words “7 years” there were substituted the words “10 years”.
In section 170 (penalty for fraudulent evasion of duty or prohibition, etc), in subsection (4A) (firearms and counterfeit currency etc)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a), for “subsection (2) or (3)” there is substituted “subsection (1) or (2)”;
for the words after “shall have effect” there is substituted “as if for the words “imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years” there were substituted the words “imprisonment for life””.

at the end of paragraph (a) of subsection (4A) there is inserted “or”;
paragraph (c) of that subsection and the word “or” before it are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In the case of an offence under subsection (1) or (2) above committed in connection with the prohibitions contained in sections 20 and 21 of the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981,
subsection (3)(b) above shall have effect as if for the words “7 years” there were substituted the words “10 years”.
In section 68 (offences in relation to exportation of prohibited or restricted goods), in subsection (4A) (firearms and counterfeit currency etc)—

P3para.Text: in paragraph (a) the words “or (3)” are omitted”;
for the words after “shall have effect” there is substituted “as if for the words “imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years” there were substituted the words “imprisonment for life””.

P2para.Text: In that section—

P3para.Text: in subsection (3), after “(4A)” there is inserted “, (4AA)”;
at the end of paragraph (a) of subsection (4A) there is inserted “or”;
paragraph (c) of that subsection and the word “or” before it are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In the case of an offence under subsection (2) above committed in connection with the prohibition contained in section 21 of the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981, subsection (3)(b) above shall have effect as if for the words “7 years” there were substituted the words “10 years”.

P1group.Title: British Transport Police: Crown status under Firearms Act 1968

P2para.Text: The following are repealed—

P3para.Text: subsections (3A) and (3B) of section 54 of the Firearms Act 1968, and
paragraph 9 of Schedule 7 to the Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001 (which inserted those subsections).

Part.Title: Protection from sexual harm and violence

P1group.Title: Sexual harm prevention orders and sexual risk orders, etc

P2para.Text: Schedule 5 (amendments of Part 2 of the Sexual Offences Act 2003) has effect.
In section 142 of the Sexual Offences Act 2003 (extent etc)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (2) (provisions that extend to Northern Ireland, as well as England and Wales), for paragraph (c) there is substituted—
sections 80 to 88, 89 to 91, 92 to 96, 96B to 103, 122F and 130 to 136ZB;
Part 2A;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: Sections 110, 117A, 119 and 123 to 129 extend only to Northern Ireland.

P3para.Text: In subsection (3) (provisions that extend to Scotland, as well as England and Wales) for paragraph (a) there is substituted—
P3para.ERROR:
ERROR:This is very likely an error in markup in the FM document. [\t(d)\t after that subsection there is inserted
\t (3A)\t Sections 88A to 88I, 96A, 111A, 117B, 120 and 121 extend only to
Scotland. \t(3B)\t Sections 104 to 109, 111, 112 to 117, 118 and 122 extend to

BlockAmendment.Text: after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: Sections 88A to 88I, 96A, 111A, 117B, 120 and 121 extend only to Scotland.
Sections 104 to 109, 111, 112 to 117, 118 and 122 extend to Northern Ireland and Scotland but not to England and Wales.
In this section—

Para.Text: “the 2003 Act” means the Sexual Offences Act 2003;
“existing order” means—
a sexual offences prevention order under section 104 of the 2003 Act;
a foreign travel order under section 114 of that Act;
a risk of sexual harm order under section 123 of that Act;
“new order” means—
a sexual harm prevention order (made under section 103A of the 2003 Act, inserted by Schedule 5);
a sexual risk order (made under section 122A of that Act, inserted by that Schedule);
“old order” means—
a restraining order under section 5A of the Sex Offenders Act 1997;
a sex offender order under section 2 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998.

P2para.Text: The repeal or amendment by this Act of sections 104 to 122 or sections 123 to 129 of the 2003 Act does not apply in relation to—

P3para.Text: an application made before the commencement day for an existing order;
an existing order (whether made before or after that day) applied for before that day;
anything done in connection with such an application or order.

P2para.Text: The following sections of the 2003 Act inserted by Schedule 5 apply (as appropriate) to an old order as they apply to a new order—

P3para.Text: section 103E (variation, renewal and discharge of sexual harm prevention order);
section 103I (offence of breach of sexual harm prevention order);
section 122E (variation, renewal and discharge of sexual risk order);
section 122H (offence of breach of sexual risk order).

P2para.Text: As from the commencement day there may be no variation of an existing order or an old order that extends the period of the order or of any of its provisions.
At the end of the period of 5 years beginning with the commencement day—

P3para.Text: in relation to any existing order or old order that is still in force, sections 103E and 103I of the 2003 Act or sections 122E and 122H of that Act (as appropriate) have effect, with any necessary modifications (and with any modifications specified in an order under section 160(7) of this Act), as if the provisions of the order were provisions of a new order;
subsections (2) and (3) cease to have effect.

P2para.Text: In this section “commencement day” means the day on which this section comes into force.
In section 98 of the Criminal Justice and Immigration Act 2008 (violent offender orders), after subsection (5) there is inserted—
The Secretary of State may by order—

P3para.Text: amend subsection (3);
make consequential amendments to subsection (4).

P2para.Text: In section 147(5) of that Act (orders etc subject to affirmative resolution procedure), after paragraph (d) there is inserted—

P3para.Text: an order under section 98(6),

P2para.Text: In section 99 of that Act (qualifying offenders), in paragraph (b) of subsection (5) (meaning of “relevant offence”) after “a specified offence” there is inserted “, or the offence of murder,”.

P1group.Title: Offence of breaching forced marriage protection order

P2para.Text: The Family Law Act 1996 is amended as follows.
After section 63C there is inserted—
A person who without reasonable excuse does anything that the person is prohibited from doing by a forced marriage protection order is guilty of an offence.

In the case of a forced marriage protection order made by virtue of section 63D(1), a person can be guilty of an offence under this section only in respect of conduct engaged in at a time when the person was aware of the existence of the order.
Where a person is convicted of an offence under this section in respect of any conduct, that conduct is not punishable as a contempt of court.
A person cannot be convicted of an offence under this section in respect of any conduct which has been punished as a contempt of court.
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years, or a fine, or both;
on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months, or a fine, or both.

P2para.Text: A reference in any enactment to proceedings under this Part, or to an order under this Part, does not include a reference to proceedings for an offence under this section or to an order made in proceedings for such an offence.
“Enactment” includes an enactment contained in subordinate legislation within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978.
For subsections (1) to (3) of section 63E there is substituted—
In any case where the court has power to make a forced marriage protection order, the court may accept an undertaking from the respondent instead of making the order.
But a court may not accept an undertaking under subsection (1) if it appears to the court—

P3para.Text: that the respondent has used or threatened violence against the person to be protected, and
that, for the person’s protection, it is necessary to make a forced marriage protection order so that any breach of it by the respondent may be punishable under section 63CA.

P2para.Text: In section 63J(2), for “the order” there is substituted “a forced marriage protection order”.
The following are repealed—

P3para.Text: section 63G(6) and (7);
section 63H;
section 63I;
section 63J(1);
in section 63K(1) the words “under section 63I(3) or”;
section 63L(4)(a).

P2para.Text: This section applies only in relation to conduct occurring on or after the day on which it comes into force.

In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, the reference to 12 months in section 63CA(5)(b) of the Family Law Act 1996 (inserted by subsection (2) above) is to be read as a reference to six months.

P1group.Title: Offence of forced marriage: England and Wales

P2para.Text: A person commits an offence under the law of England and Wales if he or she—

P3para.Text: uses violence, threats or any other form of coercion for the purpose of causing another person to enter into a marriage, and
believes, or ought reasonably to believe, that the conduct may cause the other person to enter into the marriage without free and full consent.

P2para.Text: A person commits an offence under the law of England and Wales if he or she—

P3para.Text: practises any form of deception with the intention of causing another person to leave the United Kingdom, and

intends the other person to be subjected to conduct outside the United Kingdom that is an offence under subsection (1) or would be an offence under that subsection if the victim were in England or Wales.

P2para.Text: “Marriage” means any religious or civil ceremony of marriage (whether or not legally binding).
It is irrelevant whether the conduct mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (1) is directed at the victim of the offence under that subsection or another person.
A person commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) only if, at the time of the coercion or deception—

P3para.Text: the person or the victim or both of them are in England or Wales,
neither the person nor the victim is in England or Wales but at least one of them is habitually resident in England and Wales, or
neither the person nor the victim is in the United Kingdom but at least one of them is a UK national.

P2para.Text: “UK national” means an individual who is—

P3para.Text: a British citizen, a British overseas territories citizen, a British National (Overseas) or a British Overseas citizen;
a person who under the British Nationality Act 1981 is a British subject; or
a British protected person within the meaning of that Act.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or to a fine or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years.

P2para.Text: In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003, the reference to 12 months in subsection (7)(a) is to be read as a reference to six months.
A person commits an offence under the law of Scotland if he or she—

P3para.Text: uses violence, threats or any other form of coercion for the purpose of causing another person to enter into a marriage, and
believes, or ought reasonably to believe, that the conduct may cause the other person to enter into the marriage without free and full consent.

P2para.Text: A person commits an offence under the law of Scotland if he or she—

P3para.Text: practises any form of deception with the intention of causing another person to leave the United Kingdom, and
intends the other person to be subjected to conduct outside the United Kingdom that is an offence under subsection (1) or would be an offence under that subsection if the victim were in Scotland.

P2para.Text: “Marriage” means any religious or civil ceremony of marriage (whether or not legally binding).
It is irrelevant whether the conduct mentioned in paragraph (a) of subsection (1) is directed at the victim of the offence under that subsection or another person.
A person commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) only if, at the time of the coercion or deception—

P3para.Text: the person or the victim or both of them are in Scotland,
neither the person nor the victim is in Scotland but at least one of them is habitually resident in Scotland, or
neither the person nor the victim is in the United Kingdom but at least one of them is a UK national.

P2para.Text: “UK national” means an individual who is—

P3para.Text: a British citizen, a British overseas territories citizen, a British National (Overseas) or a British Overseas citizen;
a person who under the British Nationality Act 1981 is a British subject; or
a British protected person within the meaning of that Act.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or to a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or to a fine or both.

P1group.Title: Regulations to be prepared or approved by the College

P2para.Text: In section 50 of the Police Act 1996 (regulations for police forces), after subsection (2) there is inserted—

If the College of Policing submits to the Secretary of State draft regulations with respect to any of the matters mentioned in subsection (2)(a), (b), (c) or (g), the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft unless the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: doing so would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to do so, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to do so.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations with respect to any of the matters mentioned in subsection (2)(a), (b), (c) or (g) unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.
In section 51 of that Act (regulations for special constables), after subsection (2) there is inserted—
If the College of Policing submits to the Secretary of State draft regulations with respect to—

P3para.Text: the ranks to be held by special constables,
the qualifications for appointment and promotion of special constables,
periods of service on probation, or
maintenance of personal records of special constables,

P2para.Text: the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft.
The duty in subsection (2ZA) does not apply if the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: making regulations in terms of the draft would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to make regulations in those terms, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to make regulations in those terms.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations with respect to the matters mentioned in subsection (2ZA) unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.
In section 53A of that Act (regulation of procedures and practices)—

P3para.Text: after subsection (1) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: If the College of Policing, having consulted the National Crime Agency, submits to the Secretary of State a draft of regulations under this section, the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft unless the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: doing so would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to do so, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to do so.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations under this section unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.

P3para.Text: subsections (2), (3), (4), (6), (7) and (10) are repealed;
in subsection (9), for “the first regulations to be made” there is substituted “regulations”.

P2para.Text: In section 63 of that Act (Police Advisory Board for England and Wales, etc), in subsection (3)(a), before “with respect to” there is inserted “to which section 50(2ZB) applies or regulations”.
In section 97 of the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001 (regulations about police training etc)—

P3para.Text: after subsection (1) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: If the College of Policing submits to the Secretary of State a draft of regulations under this section, the Secretary of State shall make regulations in terms of the draft unless the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: doing so would impair the efficiency or effectiveness of the police, or
it would be unlawful to do so, or
it would for some other reason be wrong to do so.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may not make regulations under this section unless the text of the regulations has been prepared or approved by the College of Policing.

P3para.Text: subsection (4) is repealed.

P1group.Title: Codes of practice issued by the College

P2para.Text: Section 39A of the Police Act 1996 (codes of practice for chief officers) is amended as follows.
For subsection (1) there is substituted—

The College of Policing may, with the approval of the Secretary of State, issue codes of practice relating to the discharge of their functions by chief officers of police if the College considers that—

P3para.Text: it is necessary to do so in order to promote the efficiency and effectiveness of police forces generally,
it is necessary to do so in order to facilitate the carrying out by members of any two or more police forces of joint or co-ordinated operations, or
it is for any other reason in the national interest to do so.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2), for “The Secretary of State may” there is substituted “The College of Policing may, with the approval of the Secretary of State,”.
For subsection (4) there is substituted—
The College of Policing shall consult with the National Crime Agency before issuing or revising a code of practice under this section.
In subsection (5), for “him” there is substituted “the College of Policing”.

P1group.Title: Guidance by the College about employment of civilian staff

P1para.Text: After section 53D of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Guidance about civilian staff employed by local policing bodies and chief officers

P2para.Text: In this section “relevant civilian staff” means individuals, other than constables, who—

P3para.Text: are employed by a local policing body or a chief officer of police, or

provide services to a local policing body or a chief officer of police, in pursuance of contractual arrangements but without being employed by the body or officer, and can be expected to have frequent contact with members of the public in the course of doing so.

P2para.Text: The College of Policing may issue guidance to local policing bodies and chief officers of police with regard to—

P3para.Text: the experience or qualifications to be expected of relevant civilian staff;
the training to be undertaken by such staff.

P2para.Text: The College may from time to time revise the whole or any part of any guidance issued under this section.
The College shall publish any guidance issued under this section and any revision of it.
In discharging any function to which guidance under this section relates, a local policing body or chief officer of police shall have regard to the guidance.

P1group.Title: Power to give directions to the College

P1para.Text: After section 40B of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Power to give directions to College of Policing

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may give a direction to the College of Policing requiring it to exercise any particular function that is conferred on the College by this Act or any other enactment.

The College of Policing shall carry out such other duties for the purpose of furthering the efficiency, effectiveness or integrity of the police as the Secretary of State may from time to time direct.

P1group.Title: Charging of fees by the College

P1para.Text: After section 95 of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Charging of fees by College of Policing

P2para.Text: The College of Policing may charge fees for providing services of a public nature only if—

P3para.Text: the services are of a specified description and are provided with a view to promoting the efficiency, effectiveness or professionalism of the police, and
the fees are of a specified amount or are determined in a specified manner.

P2para.Text: In this section “specified” means specified in an order made by the Secretary of State.
A statutory instrument containing an order under this section shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

P1group.Title: Appointment of senior police officers as staff of the College

P1para.Text: After section 100 of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Appointment of senior police officers as staff of College of Policing

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person who—

P3para.Text: holds the office of constable with a rank above that of chief superintendent, or
hold that office and is eligible to be appointed to a rank above that of chief superintendent,

P2para.Text: is appointed as a member of the staff of the College of Policing.
The person continues to hold the office of constable while a member of the staff of the College.
On appointment—

P3para.Text: a person within subsection (1)(a) holds that office with the same rank that the person held immediately before appointment, or with whatever higher rank the College decides;
a person within subsection (1)(b) holds that office with whatever rank, above that of chief superintendent, the College decides.

P1group.Title: Disclosure of information to the College

P1para.Text: After section 100A of the Police Act 1996 (inserted by section 116 above) there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Disclosure of information to College of Policing

P1para.Text: A person who, apart from this section, would not have power to disclose information to the College of Policing has power to do so where the disclosure is made for the purposes of the exercise by the College of any of its functions.
In Part 2 of the Police Reform Act 2002 (complaints and misconduct), before section 26C (inserted by section 11 of the Crime and Courts Act 2013) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: The Commission and the College of Policing must enter into an agreement for the establishment, in relation to members of the College’s staff, of procedures corresponding or similar to those provided for by or under this Part.
An agreement under this section—

P3para.Text: must not be made or varied except with the approval of the Secretary of State; and
must not be terminated unless—

P4para.Text: it is replaced by another such agreement, and
the Secretary of State approves.

P2para.Text: An agreement under this section may contain provision for enabling the Commission to bring and conduct, or otherwise participate or intervene in, any proceedings that are identified by the agreement as disciplinary hearings in relation to members of the College’s staff.
Procedures established in accordance with an agreement under this section shall have no effect in relation to anything done outside England and Wales by any member of the College’s staff.

Pblock.Title: Review bodies for police remuneration etc

P1group.Title: Abolition of Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom

P2para.Text: The Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom is abolished.
Sections 61 and 62 of the Police Act 1996 (the Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom, and its functions with respect to regulations) are repealed.

The Secretary of State may secure the reimbursement of payments made under section 61(5) or (7) of the Police Act 1996 (payment by Scottish Ministers or Department of Justice in Northern Ireland towards expenses incurred by the Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom) to the extent that, by reason of the abolition of the Board, the payments are not needed.

P1group.Title: Establishment of Police Remuneration Review Body

P2para.Text: After Part 3 of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—
There shall be a body called the Police Remuneration Review Body.
It shall consist of—

P3para.Text: a chair appointed by the Prime Minister, and
five or more other members appointed by the Secretary of State, one of whom the Secretary of State may appoint as deputy chair.

P2para.Text: Before making an appointment, the Prime Minister or the Secretary of State shall consult the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland.
The Secretary of State may by order—

P3para.Text: change the name of the body established by this section, and
make consequential amendments to any provision contained in or made under this or any other Act.

P2para.Text: A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (4) shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
Schedule 4B shall have effect in relation to the Police Remuneration Review Body.

P1group.Title: Reports by the Police Remuneration Review Body

P2para.Text: The Police Remuneration Review Body shall consider and report on any matter referred to it by the Secretary of State that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of police clothing, personal equipment and accoutrements,

P2para.Text: as regards members of police forces of or below the rank of chief superintendent or police cadets appointed under section 28.
A report under subsection (1) shall be submitted to—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State, and
the Prime Minister,

P2para.Text: and the Secretary of State shall arrange for it to be published.
The Police Remuneration Review Body shall also consider and report on any matter referred to it by the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of equipment,

P2para.Text: as regards members of the Police Service of Northern Ireland of or below the rank of chief superintendent, police trainees appointed under section 39 of the Police (Northern Ireland) Act 2000 or police cadets appointed under section 42 of that Act.
A report under subsection (3) shall be submitted to the Department of Justice, and that Department shall arrange for it to be published.
When referring a matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body, the Secretary of State or Department of Justice may give directions to that body about—

P3para.Text: the time within which it must report;
considerations to which it must have particular regard;
the evidence that it must obtain;
matters on which it is to make recommendations.

P2para.Text: The Police Remuneration Review Body may include in a report under this section any recommendations it considers appropriate arising out of matters referred to it under this section (whether or not it is required to do so by a direction under subsection (5)).
A reference or direction under this section may be varied or revoked.
After Schedule 4A to that Act there is inserted the Schedule set out in Schedule 6 to this Act.
An order under section 170(7) may include provision requiring the first members of the Police Remuneration Review Body to be, or to include, persons of a particular description.

P1group.Title: Consultation about regulations: England and Wales

P2para.Text: After section 52 of the Police Act 1996 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Regulations about hours, leave or pay: consultation etc

P2para.Text: This section applies where the Secretary of State is proposing to make regulations under section 50 or 52 on a matter that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of police clothing, personal equipment and accoutrements.

P2para.Text: In the case of regulations under section 50 concerning members of police forces of or below the rank of chief superintendent, or regulations under section 52, before making the regulations the Secretary of State shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(1), and
consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: In the case of regulations under section 50 concerning members of police forces above the rank of chief superintendent, before making the regulations the Secretary of State shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: consider advice on the matter from the Senior Salaries Review Body, or
where subsection (4) applies, refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(1) and consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies where—

P3para.Text: the regulations would affect members of police forces who are not above the rank of chief superintendent as well as those who are, and
the Secretary of State thinks that it would be preferable for the matter to be considered by the same body.

P2para.Text: The duty to consider advice from the Senior Salaries Review Body or to refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body does not apply if the Secretary of State considers that—

P3para.Text: there is not enough time to do so because the need to make the regulations is so urgent, or
it is unnecessary to do so by reason of the nature of the proposed regulations.

P2para.Text: In all cases, before making the regulations the Secretary of State shall supply a draft of them to, and consider any representations made by, persons whom the Secretary of State considers to represent the interests of—

P3para.Text: the persons and bodies who between them maintain police forces;
chief officers of police;
members of police forces;
police cadets appointed under section 28.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order amend this section in consequence of a change in the name or functions of the body for the time being specified in subsection (3)(a).
A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (7) shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
In section 63 of that Act (Police Advisory Board for England and Wales, etc), in subsection (3)(a), for “regulations with respect to any of the matters mentioned
in section 61(1)” there is substituted “regulations of a kind referred to in section 52A(1)”.
In section 1 of the Police Pensions Act 1976 (police pensions regulations)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1), for “the Police Negotiating Board for the United Kingdom” there is substituted “the appropriate advisory or negotiating body”;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In subsection (1) above, “the appropriate advisory or negotiating body” means—

P3para.Text: as regards England and Wales, the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales;
as regards Scotland, the Police Negotiating Board for Scotland.

P2para.Text: When carrying out consultation under subsection (1) above as regards England and Wales, the Secretary of State shall also invite the views of the Northern Ireland Policing Board and the Police Association for Northern Ireland.
In section 52 of the Police Act 1996 (regulations for police cadets), at the end there is inserted—

Before making regulations under this section relating to pensions the Secretary of State shall consult with the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales and shall also invite the views of the Northern Ireland Policing Board and the Police Association for Northern Ireland.
In Schedule 3 to the Police and Justice Act 2006 (power to merge police pension schemes), in paragraph 3, for sub-paragraph (3) there is substituted—
The Secretary of State shall—

P3para.Text: consult with the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales before exercising the power as regards England and Wales;
consult with the Police Negotiating Board for Scotland before exercising the power as regards Scotland;
consult with the Northern Ireland Policing Board and the Police Association for Northern Ireland before exercising the power as regards Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: In section 25 of the Police (Northern Ireland) Act 1998 (regulations for the Police Service of Northern Ireland)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (8), the words “, other than regulations made by virtue of subsection (2)(j), (k) or (l)” are omitted;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: Subsection (8) does not apply to—

P3para.Text: regulations made by virtue of subsection (2)(k), as to which the Department of Justice shall invite the views of the Police Advisory Board for England and Wales, or
regulations made by virtue of subsection (2)(j) or (l), as to which section 25A applies.

P2para.Text: After that section there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Regulations about hours, leave, pay or equipment: consultation etc

P2para.Text: This section applies where the Department of Justice is proposing to make regulations under section 25 by virtue of subsection (2)(j) or (l) of that section.
In the case of regulations concerning officers of or below the rank of chief superintendent, before making the regulations the Department of Justice shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(3) of the Police Act 1996, and
consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: In the case of regulations concerning officers above the rank of chief superintendent, before making the regulations the Department of Justice shall (subject to subsection (5))—

P3para.Text: consider advice on the matter from the Senior Salaries Review Body, or
where subsection (4) applies, refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(3) of the Police Act 1996 and consider that body’s report on the matter.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies where—

P3para.Text: the regulations would affect officers who are not above the rank of chief superintendent as well as those who are, and
the Department of Justice thinks that it would be preferable for the matter to be considered by the same body.

P2para.Text: The duty to consider advice from the Senior Salaries Review Body or to refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body does not apply if Department of Justice considers that—

P3para.Text: there is not enough time to do so because the need to make the regulations is so urgent, or
it is unnecessary to do so by reason of the nature of the proposed regulations.

P2para.Text: In all cases, before making the regulations the Department of Justice shall supply a draft of them to, and consider any representations made by—

P3para.Text: the Board,
the Police Association, and
the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: The Department of Justice may by order amend this section in consequence of a change in the name or functions of the body for the time being specified in subsection (3)(a).
In section 41 of the Police (Northern Ireland) Act 2000 (police trainees and police reserve trainees)—

P3para.Text: at the end of subsection (6) there is inserted “, other than regulations to which subsection (8) applies”;
after that subsection there is inserted—

P2para.Text: Subsection (8) applies to regulations under subsection (3), concerning police trainees, on a matter that relates to—

P3para.Text: hours of duty,
leave,
pay and allowances, or
the issue, use and return of equipment.

P2para.Text: Before making any such regulations the Department of Justice shall—

P3para.Text: (subject to subsection (9)) refer the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body under section 64B(3) of the Police Act 1996 and consider that body’s report on the matter, and
supply a draft of the regulations to, and consider any representations made by—

P4para.Text: the Board,
the Police Association, and
the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: The duty in subsection (8)(a) does not apply if the Department of Justice considers that—

P3para.Text: there is not enough time to refer to the matter to the Police Remuneration Review Body because the need to make the regulations is so urgent, or
it is unnecessary to do so by reason of the nature of the proposed regulations.

P1group.Title: Application of IPCC provisions to contractors

P1para.Text: In section 12 of the Police Reform Act 2002 (complaints, matters and persons to which Part 2 applies), at the end there is inserted—

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may make regulations providing that, for the purposes of this Part and of any regulations made under this Part—

P3para.Text: a contractor,
a sub-contractor of a contractor, or
an employee of a contractor or a sub-contractor,

P2para.Text: is to be treated as a person serving with the police.
Regulations under subsection (8) may make modifications to this Part, and to any regulations made under this Part, in its application to those persons.
In subsection (8) “contractor” means a person who has entered into a contract with a local policing body or a chief officer to provide services to a chief officer.

P1group.Title: Application to IPCC of provisions about investigation of offences

P2para.Text: In Schedule 3 to the Police Reform Act 2002 (handling of complaints and conduct matters etc), paragraph 19 (investigations by the Independent Police Complaints Commission itself) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (6), for the words from “provide that such provisions” to “shall apply” there is substituted “provide that—

P3para.Text: such provisions of the 1984 Act relating to investigations of offences conducted by police officers as may be specified in the order, and
such provisions of a code of practice under section 60, 60A or 66 of that Act as may be so specified,

P2para.Text: shall apply
After sub-paragraph (6) there is inserted—

An order under sub-paragraph (6) may, in particular, provide that where a provision applied by the order allows a power to be exercised only if an authorisation is given by a police officer of or above a particular rank, the authorisation may be given by a member of the Commission’s staff of or above a specified grade.

P1para.Text: After paragraph 19 of Schedule 3 to the Police Reform Act 2002 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Investigations by the Commission: power to serve information notice

P2para.Text: The Commission may serve upon any person an information notice requiring the person to provide it with information that it reasonably requires for the purposes of an investigation in accordance with paragraph 19.
But an information notice must not require a person—

P3para.Text: to provide information that might incriminate the person;
to provide an item subject to legal privilege within the meaning of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (see section 10 of that Act);
to make a disclosure that would be prohibited by Part 1 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000;

to provide information that was provided to the person by, or by an agency of, the Government of a country or territory outside the United Kingdom where that Government does not consent to the disclosure of the information.

P2para.Text: Neither must an information notice require a postal or telecommunications operator (within the meaning of Chapter 2 of Part 1 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000) to provide communications data (within the meaning of that Chapter).
An information notice must—

P3para.Text: specify or describe the information that is required by the Commission and the form in which it must be provided;
specify the period within which the information must be provided;
give details of the right of appeal against the information notice under paragraph 19ZC.

P2para.Text: The period specified under sub-paragraph (4)(b) must not end before the end of the period within which an appeal can be brought against the notice and, if such an appeal is brought, the information need not be provided pending the determination or withdrawal of the appeal.
The Commission may cancel an information notice by written notice to the person on whom it was served.

P1group.Title: Failure to comply with information notice

P2para.Text: If a person who has received an information notice—

P3para.Text: fails or refuses to provide the information required by the notice, or
knowingly or recklessly provides information in response to the notice that is false in a material respect,

P2para.Text: the Commission may certify in writing to the High Court that the person has failed to comply with the information notice.

The High Court may then inquire into the matter and, after hearing any witness who may be produced against or on behalf of the person, and after hearing any statement offered in defence, deal with the person as if the person had committed a contempt of court.
A person on whom an information notice is served may appeal against the notice to the First-tier Tribunal on the ground that the notice is not in accordance with the law.
If the Tribunal considers that the notice is not in accordance with the law—

P3para.Text: it must quash the notice, and
it may give directions to the Commission in relation to the service of a further information notice.

P1group.Title: Sensitive information: restriction on further disclosure

P2para.Text: Where the Commission receives information within sub-paragraph (2) under an information notice, it must not disclose (whether under section 11, 20 or 21 or otherwise) the information, or the fact that it has received it, unless the relevant authority consents to the disclosure.
The information is—

P3para.Text: intelligence service information,
intercept information, or
information obtained (directly or indirectly) from a government department which, at the time it is provided to the Commission, is identified by the department as
information the disclosure of which may, in the opinion of the relevant authority, cause damage to—

P4para.Text: national security or international relations, or
the economic interests of the United Kingdom or any part of the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: Where the Commission discloses to another person information within sub-paragraph (2), or the fact that it has received it, that person must not disclose that information or that fact unless the relevant authority consents to the disclosure.
In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “government department” means a department of Her Majesty’s Government but does not include—
the Security Service,
the Secret Intelligence Service, or
the Government Communications Headquarters (“GCHQ”);
“intelligence service information” means information which was obtained (directly or indirectly) from an intelligence service or which relates to an intelligence service;
“intelligence service” means—
the Security Service,
the Secret Intelligence Service,
GCHQ, or
any part of Her Majesty’s forces (within the meaning of the Armed Forces Act 2006), or of the Ministry of Defence, which engages in intelligence activities;
“intercept information” means information relating to any of the matters mentioned in section 19(3) of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000;
“Minister of the Crown” includes the Treasury;
“relevant authority” means—
in the case of intelligence service information obtained from the Security Service, the Director-General of the Security Service;
in the case of intelligence service information obtained from the Secret Intelligence Service, the Chief of the Secret Intelligence Service;
in the case of intelligence service information received from GCHQ, the Director of GCHQ;
in the case of intelligence service information obtained from Her Majesty’s forces or the Ministry of Defence, the Secretary of State;
in the case of intercept information, the person to whom the relevant interception warrant is or was addressed;
in the case of information within sub-paragraph (2)(c)—
the Secretary of State, or
the Minister of the Crown in charge of the government department from which the
information was obtained (if that Minister is not a Secretary of State);
“relevant interception warrant” means the interception warrant issued under section 5 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 that relates to the intercept information.

P1group.Title: Unsatisfactory performance procedures following investigation of death or serious injury matter

P2para.Text: In paragraph 24C of Schedule 3 to the Police Reform Act 2002 (cases of death or serious injury where Independent Police Complaints Commission determines that disciplinary proceedings not justified), at the end there is inserted—
The Commission may notify the appropriate authority that it must, in accordance with regulations under section 50 or 51 of the 1996 Act, determine—

P3para.Text: whether or not the performance of a person serving with the police is unsatisfactory, and
what action (if any) the authority will take in respect of any such person’s performance.

P2para.Text: On receipt of a notification under sub-paragraph (3) the appropriate authority shall make those determinations and submit a memorandum to the Commission setting out the determinations the authority has made.
On receipt of a memorandum under sub-paragraph (4), the Commission shall—

P3para.Text: consider the memorandum and whether the appropriate authority has made the determinations under sub-paragraph (4) that the Commission considers appropriate;
determine whether or not to make recommendations under paragraph 27;
make such recommendations (if any) under that paragraph as it thinks fit.

P2para.Text: Paragraph 27 of that Schedule (duties with respect to disciplinary proceedings) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (1), at the end there is inserted “; or

P3para.Text: has submitted, or is required to submit, a memorandum to the Commission under paragraph 24C(4).

P2para.Text: After sub-paragraph (3) there is inserted—
Where this paragraph applies by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)(c), the Commission may make a recommendation to the appropriate authority—

P3para.Text: that the performance of a person serving with the police is, or is not, satisfactory;
that action of the form specified in the recommendation is taken in respect of the person’s performance;

P2para.Text: and it shall be the duty of the appropriate authority to notify the Commission whether it accepts the recommendation and (if it does)
to set out in the notification the steps that it is proposing to take to give effect to it.

P1group.Title: Recommendations by IPCC and requirement to respond

P1para.Text: After paragraph 28 of Schedule 3 to the Police Reform Act 2002 there is inserted—

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where the Commission has received a report under—

P3para.Text: paragraph 22(3) (report on completion of investigation of complaint or conduct matter supervised or managed by Commission),
paragraph 22(5) (report on completion of investigation of complaint or conduct matter by Commission itself ), or
paragraph 24A(2) (report on completion of investigation of DSI matter that is not also conduct matter).

P2para.Text: This paragraph also applies where the Commission has made a determination on an appeal under—

P3para.Text: paragraph 8A (appeal relating to complaint dealt with other than by investigation), or
paragraph 25 (appeal with respect to an investigation).

P2para.Text: The Commission may make a recommendation in relation to a matter dealt with in the report or appeal.
A recommendation under this paragraph may be made to any person if it is made—

P3para.Text: following the receipt of a report relating to—

P4para.Text: a DSI matter,
a conduct matter of a type specified in regulations, or
a complaint of a type specified in regulations; or

P3para.Text: following a determination on an appeal relating to a complaint of a type specified in regulations.

P2para.Text: In any other case, a recommendation under this paragraph may be made only to—

P3para.Text: a person serving with the police, or
a local policing body.

P2para.Text: Where the Commission makes a recommendation under this paragraph, it must also—

P3para.Text: publish the recommendation, and
send a copy of it—

P4para.Text: in a case where the recommendation is made to a local policing body, to the chief officer of the police force maintained by that body;
in a case where the recommendation is made to a chief officer of a police force, to the local policing body that maintains the police force;

in a case where the recommendation is made to a contractor (within the meaning of section 12(10)), to the chief officer of a police force to whom the contractor is providing services, and the local policing body that maintains the police force;
in a case where the recommendation is made to a sub-contractor or an employee of a contractor, to the contractor and the persons to whom a copy must be sent under paragraph (iii);
in a case where the recommendation is made to an employee of a sub-contractor, to the sub-contractor, the contractor and the persons to whom a copy must be sent under sub-paragraph (iii);
in any other case, to any person to whom the Commission thinks a copy should be sent.

P2para.Text: Nothing in this paragraph affects the power of the Commission to make recommendations or give advice under section 10(1)(e) (whether arising under this Schedule or otherwise).
A person to whom a recommendation under paragraph 28A is made must provide to the Commission a response in writing stating—

P3para.Text: what action the person has taken or proposes to take in response to the recommendation, or
why the person has not taken, or does not propose to take, any action in response.

P2para.Text: The person must provide the response to the Commission before the end of the period of 56 days beginning with the day on which the recommendation was made, unless sub-paragraph (3) applies.

The Commission may extend the period of 56 days following an application received before the end of the period; and if the Commission grants an extension, the person must provide the response before the end of the extended period.

But if proceedings for judicial review of the Commission’s decision to make a recommendation are started during the period allowed by sub-paragraph (2) or (3), that period is extended by however many days the proceedings are in progress.
On receiving a response, the Commission must, within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the Commission received it—

P3para.Text: publish the response, and
send a copy of it to any person who was sent a copy of the recommendation under paragraph 28A(6)(b),

P2para.Text: unless the person giving the response has made representations under sub-paragraph (6).

The person giving the response may, at the time of providing it to the Commission, make representations to the Commission asserting that the requirements of publication and disclosure under sub-paragraph (5) should not apply to the response, or to particular parts of it.
On receiving such representations, the Commission may decide—

P3para.Text: that the response should not be published, or that only parts of it should be published;
that the response should not be disclosed, or that only parts of the response should be disclosed.

P2para.Text: Where, following a decision on representations, the Commission decides to publish or disclose a response (in whole or in part), it must do so only after the person giving the response has been informed of the Commission’s decision, and—

P3para.Text: in a case where the Commission has decided to accept all of the representations, it must do so within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which it received the response;
in a case where the Commission has decided to reject any of the representations, it must do so—

P4para.Text: within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the person was informed of the Commission’s decision on the representations, but
not before the end of the period of 7 days beginning with that day.

P2para.Text: But if proceedings for judicial review of the Commission’s decision to reject a representation are started during the period of 7 days referred to in sub-paragraph (8)(b)(ii)—

P3para.Text: the Commission must not publish or disclose the response while the proceedings are in progress;

if the court upholds the Commission’s decision to reject a representation, the Commission must publish and disclose the response (in whole or in part, as appropriate) before the end of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which the proceedings are no longer in progress.

P2para.Text: Where a local policing body or a chief officer makes a response under this paragraph, the body or officer must, at the time the Commission publishes the response, also publish the response (to the same extent as published by the Commission) and the recommendation under paragraph 28A.
For the purposes of this paragraph—

P3para.Text: “disclosing” a response means sending a copy of it as mentioned in sub-paragraph (5)(b);
the period during which judicial review proceedings are in progress includes any day on which an appeal is in progress or may be brought.

Pblock.Title: Chief officers of police and local policing bodies

P1group.Title: Appointment of chief officers of police

P2para.Text: Paragraph 2 of Schedule 8 to the Police Reform and Social Responsibility Act 2011 (appointment of chief constables) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (1)(a), for “is, or has been, a constable in any part of the United Kingdom” there is substituted “is eligible for appointment”.
After sub-paragraph (1) there is inserted—
A person is eligible for appointment if the person is or has been—

P3para.Text: a constable in any part of the United Kingdom, or
a police officer in an approved overseas police force, of at least the approved rank.

P2para.Text: An “approved overseas police force” is a police force which—

P3para.Text: is in a country or territory outside the United Kingdom designated by regulations made by the Secretary of State, and
is designated in relation to that country or territory by the regulations.

P2para.Text: The “approved rank” for an approved overseas police force is the rank which is designated as the approved rank for that police force by the regulations.
The College of Policing must recommend to the Secretary of State matters to be designated under this paragraph.
The Secretary of State may make regulations under this paragraph only if they give effect to a recommendation under sub-paragraph (1D).
Section 42 of that Act (appointment of Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis) is amended as follows.
In subsection (3), for “is, or has been, a constable in any part of the United Kingdom” there is substituted “is eligible for appointment”.
After subsection (3) there is inserted—
A person is eligible for appointment if the person is or has been—

P3para.Text: a constable in any part of the United Kingdom, or
a police officer in an approved overseas police force, of at least the approved rank.

P2para.Text: An “approved overseas police force” is a police force which—

P3para.Text: is in a country or territory outside the United Kingdom designated by regulations made by the Secretary of State, and
is designated in relation to that country or territory by the regulations.

P2para.Text: The “approved rank” for an approved overseas police force is the rank which is designated as the approved rank for that police force by the regulations.
The College of Policing must recommend to the Secretary of State matters to be designated under this section.
The Secretary of State may make regulations under this section only if they give effect to a recommendation under subsection (3D).

P3para.Text: for the purpose of meeting expenses pending the receipt of revenues receivable by the chief constable in respect of the period of account in which the expenses are chargeable,
in sterling, and
with the consent of the relevant police and crime commissioner.

P2para.Text: A chief constable—

P3para.Text: may not borrow money except as permitted by sub-paragraph (1);

P2para.Text: A chief constable may invest—

P3para.Text: for any purpose relevant to the chief constable’s functions under any enactment, or
for the purpose of the prudent management of the chief constable’s financial affairs,

Regulations made by the Welsh Ministers under any of those provisions apply in relation to the chief constable of a police force in Wales as they apply in relation to a local authority in Wales.

Any of those provisions, or regulations made under them, that apply for the purposes of Chapter 1 of Part 1 of the Local Government Act 2003 apply also (so far as relevant) for the purposes of sub-paragraphs (1) to (3).
