P1group.Title: Powers of local policing bodies to provide or commission services

P2para.Text: A local policing body may provide or arrange for the provision of—

P3para.Text: services that in the opinion of the local policing body will secure, or contribute to securing, crime and disorder reduction in the body’s area;
services that are intended by the local policing body to help victims or witnesses of, or other persons affected by, offences and anti-social behaviour;
services of a description specified in an order made by the Secretary of State.

P2para.Text: An order under subsection (1)(c) may make different provision for different areas.
A local policing body arranging for the provision of services under this section may make grants in connection with the arrangements.
A grant may be subject to any conditions (including conditions as to repayment) that the local policing body thinks appropriate.
A grant may be subject to any conditions (including conditions as to repayment) that the local policing body thinks appropriate.
In this section—

Para.Text: “anti-social behaviour” means behaviour by a person that causes or is likely to cause harassment, alarm or distress to one or more other persons not of the same household as that person;
“crime and disorder reduction” means reduction in levels of—
crime and disorder (including anti-social behaviour and other behaviour adversely affecting the local environment),
the misuse of drugs, alcohol and other substances, and
re-offending.

P1group.Title: Information about guests at hotels believed to be used for child sexual exploitation

P2para.Text: A police officer of at least the rank of inspector may issue a notice under this section to the owner, operator or manager of a hotel that the officer reasonably believes has been or will be used for the purposes of—

P3para.Text: child sexual exploitation, or
conduct that is preparatory to, or otherwise connected with, child sexual exploitation.

P2para.Text: A notice under this section must be in writing and must—

P3para.Text: specify the hotel to which it relates;
specify the date on which it comes into effect and the date on which it expires;
explain the effect of subsections (4) and (5) and sections 133 and 134.

P2para.Text: The date on which the notice expires must not be more than 6 months after the date on which it comes into effect.
A constable may require a person issued with a notice under this section to provide the constable with information about guests at the hotel.
The only information that a constable may require under subsection (4) is—

P3para.Text: guests’ names and addresses;
other information about guests that—

P4para.Text: is specified in regulations made by the Secretary of State, and
can be readily obtained from one or more of the guests themselves.

P2para.Text: A requirement under subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: must be in writing;
must specify the period to which the requirement relates;
must specify the date or dates on or by which the required information is to be provided.

P2para.Text: The period specified under paragraph (b) must begin no earlier than the time when the requirement is imposed and must end no later than the expiry of the notice under this section.
In this section—

Para.Text: “child sexual exploitation” means conduct that constitutes an offence listed in subsection (8)(a) or (b), or an offence listed in subsection (8)(c) against a person under 18;
“guest” means a person who, for a charge payable by that person or another, has the use of a guest room at the hotel in question;
“hotel” includes any guest house or other establishment of a similar kind at which accommodation is provided for a charge.

P2para.Text: The offences are—

P3para.Text: an offence under any of the following sections of the Sexual Offences Act 2003—

Para.Text: sections 5 to 8 (rape and other offences against children under 13);
sections 9 to 13 (child sex offences);
sections 16 to 19 (abuse of position of trust);
sections 25 and 26 (familial child sex offences);
sections 47 to 50 (abuse of children through prostitution and pornography);

P3para.Text: an offence under section 1 of the Protection of Children Act 1978 (indecent photographs of children);
an offence under any of the following sections of the Sexual Offences Act 2003—

Para.Text: sections 1 to 4 (rape, assault and causing sexual activity without consent);
sections 30 to 41 (persons with a mental disorder impeding choice, inducements etc to persons with a mental disorder, and care workers for persons with a mental disorder);
section 59A (trafficking people for sexual exploitation);
section 61 (administering a substance with intent);
sections 66 and 67 (exposure and voyeurism).

P2para.Text: A person issued with a notice under section 132 may appeal against it to a magistrates’ court.
An appeal must be made within the period of 21 days beginning with the day on which the person is issued with the notice.
Where there is an appeal against a notice under section 132, then until the appeal is finally determined or withdrawn—

P3para.Text: no requirement may be imposed under subsection (4) of that section in relation to the premises in question;
any such requirement already imposed is of no effect.

P2para.Text: A magistrates’ court hearing an appeal against a notice under section 132 must—

P3para.Text: quash the notice,
modify the notice, or
dismiss the appeal.

P2para.Text: An offence is committed by a person who fails without reasonable excuse to comply with a requirement imposed on the person under 132(4).
An offence is committed by a person who, in response to a requirement imposed on the person under section 132(4), provides incorrect information which the person—

P3para.Text: did not take reasonable steps to verify or to have verified, or
knows to be incorrect.

P2para.Text: A person does not commit an offence under subsection (2)(a) if there were no steps that the person could reasonably have taken to verify the information or to have it verified.
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale.

P2para.Text: The amendment made by subsection (1) applies even where the event referred to in subsection (1)(b) of the substituted section 63P occurs before the day on which this section comes into force.

P1group.Title: Retention of personal samples that are or may be disclosable

P3para.Text: falls within subsection (5), and

P2para.Text: must not be used other than for the purposes of any proceedings for the offence in connection with which the sample was taken.

A sample that once fell within subsection (5) but no longer does, and so becomes a sample to which section 63R applies, must be destroyed immediately if the time specified for its destruction under that section has already passed.

A sample that once fell within sub-paragraph (1) but no longer does, and so becomes a sample to which paragraph 20G applies, must be destroyed immediately if the time specified for its destruction under that paragraph has already passed.

P1group.Title: Extradition barred if no prosecution decision in requesting territory

P2para.Text: In section 11 of the Extradition Act 2003 (bars to extradition), after paragraph (a) of subsection (1) there is inserted—

P3para.Text: absence of prosecution decision;

P2para.Text: After section 12 of that Act there is inserted—
A person’s extradition to a category 1 territory is barred by reason of absence of prosecution decision if (and only if)—

P3para.Text: it appears to the appropriate judge that there are reasonable grounds for believing that—

P4para.Text: the competent authorities in the category 1 territory have not made a decision to charge or have not made a decision to try (or have made neither of those decisions), and
the person’s absence from the category 1 territory is not the sole reason for that failure,

P3para.Text: and
those representing the category 1 territory do not prove that—

P4para.Text: the competent authorities in the category 1 territory have made a decision to charge and a decision to try, or
in a case where one of those decisions has not been made (or neither of them has been made), the person’s absence from the category 1 territory is the sole reason for that failure.

P2para.Text: In this section “to charge” and “to try”, in relation to a person and an extradition offence, mean—

P3para.Text: to charge the person with the offence in the category 1 territory, and
to try the person for the offence in the category 1 territory.

P2para.Text: In a case where the Part 1 warrant (within the meaning of the Extradition Act 2003) has been issued before the time when the amendments made by this section come into force, those amendments apply to the extradition concerned only if, at that time, the judge has not yet decided all of the questions in section 11(1) of that Act.
In section 11 of the Extradition Act 2003 (bars to extradition), in subsection (5), for “21” there is substituted “21A”.
After section 21 of that Act there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Person not convicted: human rights and proportionality

P2para.Text: If the judge is required to proceed under this section (by virtue of section 11), the judge must decide both of the following questions in respect of the extradition of the person (“D”)—

P3para.Text: whether the extradition would be compatible with the Convention rights within the meaning of the Human Rights Act 1998;
whether the extradition would be disproportionate.

P2para.Text: In deciding whether the extradition would be disproportionate, the judge must take into account the specified matters relating to proportionality (so far as the judge thinks it appropriate to do so); but the judge must not take any other matters into account.
These are the specified matters relating to proportionality—

P3para.Text: the seriousness of the conduct alleged to constitute the extradition offence;
the likely penalty that would be imposed if D was found guilty of the extradition offence;
the possibility of the relevant foreign authorities taking measures that would be less coercive than the extradition of D.

P2para.Text: The judge must order D’s discharge if the judge makes one or both of these decisions—

P3para.Text: that the extradition would not be compatible with the Convention rights;
that the extradition would be disproportionate.

P2para.Text: The judge must order D to be extradited to the category 1 territory in which the warrant was issued if the judge makes both of these decisions—

P3para.Text: that the extradition would be compatible with the Convention rights;
that the extradition would not be disproportionate.

P2para.Text: If the judge makes an order under subsection (5) he must remand the person in custody or on bail to wait for extradition to the category 1 territory.
If the person is remanded in custody, the appropriate judge may later grant bail.
In this section “relevant foreign authorities” means the authorities in the territory to which D would be extradited if the extradition went ahead.

In deciding that question, the designated authority must apply any general guidance issued for the purposes of this subsection.
In deciding that question, the designated authority must apply any general guidance issued for the purposes of this subsection.
Any guidance under subsection (7A) may be revised, withdrawn or replaced.

The function of issuing guidance under subsection (7A), or of revising, withdrawing or replacing any such guidance, is exercisable by the Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales with the concurrence of—

P3para.Text: the Lord Justice General of Scotland, and

P2para.Text: In deciding any question whether section 21A of the Extradition Act 2003 is compatible with European Union law, regard must be had (in particular) to Article 1(3) of the framework decision of the Council of the European Union made on 13 June 2002 on the European arrest warrant and the surrender procedures between member states (2002/584/JHA) (which provides that that decision shall not have the effect of modifying the obligation to respect fundamental rights and fundamental legal principles as enshrined in Article 6 of the Treaty on European Union).

P1para.Text: Before section 22 of the Extradition Act 2003 there is inserted—

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: a Part 1 warrant is issued which contains the statement referred to in section 2(3) (warrant issued for purposes of prosecution for offence in category 1 territory), and
at any time before or in the extradition hearing, the appropriate judge is informed that a request under subsection (2) or (3) has been made.

P2para.Text: A request under this subsection is a request by a judicial authority of the category 1 territory in which the warrant is issued (“the requesting territory”)—

P3para.Text: that the person in respect of whom the warrant is issued be temporarily transferred to the requesting territory, or

that arrangements be made to enable the person to speak with representatives of an authority in the requesting territory responsible for investigating, prosecuting or trying the offence specified in the warrant.

P2para.Text: A request under this subsection is a request by the person in respect of whom the warrant is issued—

P3para.Text: to be temporarily transferred to the requesting territory, or

that arrangements be made to enable the person to speak with representatives of an authority in the requesting territory responsible for investigating, prosecuting or trying the offence specified in the warrant.

P2para.Text: The judge must order further proceedings in respect of the extradition to be adjourned if the judge thinks it necessary to do so to enable the person (in the case of a request under subsection (2)) or the authority by
which the warrant is issued (in the case of a request under subsection (3)) to consider whether to consent to the request.
An adjournment under this subsection must not be for more than 7 days.
An adjournment under this subsection must not be for more than 7 days.
If the person or authority consents to the request, the judge must—

P3para.Text: make whatever orders and directions seem appropriate for giving effect to the request;
order further proceedings in respect of the extradition to be adjourned for however long seems necessary to enable the orders and directions to be carried out.

P2para.Text: If the request, or consent to the request, is withdrawn before effect (or full effect) has been given to it—

P3para.Text: no steps (or further steps) may be taken to give effect to the request;
the judge may make whatever further orders and directions seem appropriate (including an order superseding one made under subsection (5)(b)).

P2para.Text: A person may not make a request under paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (3) in respect of a warrant if the person has already given consent to a request under the corresponding paragraph of subsection (2) in respect of that warrant (even if that consent has been withdrawn).

A person may not make a further request under paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (3) in respect of a warrant if the person has already made a request under that paragraph in respect of that warrant (even if that request has been withdrawn).
If—

the proceedings are adjourned under this section,

P1group.Title: Judge informed after extradition hearing or order that person charged with offence or serving sentence in United Kingdom

P2para.Text: After section 36 of the Extradition Act 2003 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Judge informed after extradition hearing that person charged with offence in United Kingdom

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: an order has been made for the extradition of the person in respect of whom the Part 1 warrant is issued, and
before the extradition order is carried out the appropriate judge is informed that the person is charged with an offence in the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: The appropriate judge must order the extradition order not to be carried out until one of these occurs—

P3para.Text: the charge is disposed of;
the charge is withdrawn;
proceedings in respect of the charge are discontinued;
an order is made for the charge to lie on the file, or in relation to Scotland, the diet is deserted pro loco et tempore.

P2para.Text: If a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention is imposed in respect of the offence charged, the appropriate judge may order the extradition order not to be carried out until the person is released from detention pursuant to the sentence (whether on licence or otherwise).
Rules of court may provide that where there is an appeal against the extradition order —

P3para.Text: a reference in this section to the appropriate judge has effect, in prescribed circumstances, as if it were a reference to the court hearing the appeal, and
this section has effect with any other prescribed modifications.

P1group.Title: Judge informed after extradition hearing that person serving sentence in United Kingdom

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: an order has been made for the extradition of the person in respect of whom the Part 1 warrant is issued, and
before the extradition order is carried out the appropriate judge is informed that the person is serving a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention in the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: The appropriate judge may order the extradition order not to be carried out until the person is released from detention pursuant to the sentence (whether on licence or otherwise).
Rules of court may provide that where there is an appeal against the extradition order —

P3para.Text: a reference in this section to the appropriate judge has effect, in prescribed circumstances, as if it were a reference to the court hearing the appeal, and
this section has effect with any other prescribed modifications.

P2para.Text: After section 118 of that Act there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Judge informed after extradition order that person charged with offence in United Kingdom

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: the Secretary of State has made an order for a person’s extradition under this Part, and
before the extradition order is carried out the appropriate judge is informed that the person is charged with an offence in the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: The appropriate judge must order the extradition order not to be carried out until one of these occurs—

P3para.Text: the charge is disposed of;
the charge is withdrawn;
proceedings in respect of the charge are discontinued;
an order is made for the charge to lie on the file, or in relation to Scotland, the diet is deserted pro loco et tempore.

P2para.Text: If a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention is imposed in respect of the offence charged, the appropriate judge may order the extradition order not to be carried out until the person is released from detention pursuant to the sentence (whether on licence or otherwise).
Rules of court may provide that where there is an appeal against the extradition order —

P3para.Text: a reference in this section to the appropriate judge has effect, in prescribed circumstances, as if it were a reference to the court hearing the appeal, and
this section has effect with any other prescribed modifications.

Rules of court may provide that where there is an appeal against the extradition order —

P3para.Text: a reference in this section to the appropriate judge has effect, in prescribed circumstances, as if it were a reference to the court hearing the appeal, and
this section has effect with any other prescribed modifications.

P1group.Title: Consent to extradition not to be taken as waiver of speciality rights

P1para.Text: In the Extradition Act 2003 the following provisions are repealed—

section 128(5).

P2para.Text: For sections 64 and 65 of the Extradition Act 2003 there is substituted—

P1group.Title: Extradition offences: person not sentenced for offence

P2para.Text: This section sets out whether a person’s conduct constitutes an “extradition offence” for the purposes of this Part in a case where the person—

P3para.Text: is accused in a category 1 territory of an offence constituted by the conduct, or
has been convicted in that territory of an offence constituted by the conduct but not sentenced for it.

P2para.Text: The conduct constitutes an extradition offence in relation to the category 1 territory if the conditions in subsection (3), (4) or (5) are satisfied.
The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs in the category 1 territory;
the conduct would constitute an offence under the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom if it occurred in that part of the United Kingdom;
the conduct is punishable under the law of the category 1 territory with imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 12 months or a greater punishment.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs outside the category 1 territory;
in corresponding circumstances equivalent conduct would constitute an extra-territorial offence under the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom;
the conduct is punishable under the law of the category 1 territory with imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 12 months or a greater punishment.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs in the category 1 territory;
no part of the conduct occurs in the United Kingdom;
a certificate issued by an appropriate authority of the category 1 territory shows that the conduct falls within the European framework list;
the certificate shows that the conduct is punishable under the law of the category 1 territory with imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 3 years or a greater punishment.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsections (3)(b) and (4)(b)—

P3para.Text: if the conduct relates to a tax or duty, it does not matter whether the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom imposes the same kind of tax or duty or contains rules of the same kind as those of the law of the category 1 territory;

if the conduct relates to customs or exchange, it does not matter whether the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom contains rules of the same kind as those of the law of the category 1 territory.

P1group.Title: Extradition offences: person sentenced for offence

P2para.Text: This section sets out whether a person’s conduct constitutes an “extradition offence” for the purposes of this Part in a case where the person—

P3para.Text: has been convicted in a category 1 territory of an offence constituted by the conduct, and
has been sentenced for the offence.

P2para.Text: The conduct constitutes an extradition offence in relation to the category 1 territory if the conditions in subsection (3), (4) or (5) are satisfied.
The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs in the category 1 territory;
the conduct would constitute an offence under the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom if it occurred in that part of the United Kingdom;
a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 4 months or a greater punishment has been imposed in the category 1 territory in respect of the conduct.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs outside the category 1 territory;
in corresponding circumstances equivalent conduct would constitute an extra-territorial offence under the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom;
a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 4 months or a greater punishment has been imposed in the category 1 territory in respect of the conduct.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs in the category 1 territory;
no part of the conduct occurs in the United Kingdom;
a certificate issued by an appropriate authority of the category 1 territory shows that the conduct falls within the European framework list;

the certificate shows that a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 4 months or a greater punishment has been imposed in the category 1 territory in respect of the conduct.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsections (3)(b) and (4)(b)—

P3para.Text: if the conduct relates to a tax or duty, it does not matter whether the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom imposes the same kind of tax or duty or contains rules of the same kind as those of the law of the category 1 territory;

if the conduct relates to customs or exchange, it does not matter whether the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom contains rules of the same kind as those of the law of the category 1 territory.

P2para.Text: In section 66 (supplementary provision for the purposes of sections 64 and 65) after subsection (1) there is inserted—
References to “conduct” (except in the expression “equivalent conduct”) are to the conduct specified in the Part 1 warrant.
In section 137 of that Act (definition of extradition offence for the purposes of Part 2 of the Act: person not sentenced for offence) for subsections (1) to (5) there is substituted—
This section sets out whether a person’s conduct constitutes an “extradition offence” for the purposes of this Part in a case where the person—

P3para.Text: is accused in a category 2 territory of an offence constituted by the conduct, or
has been convicted in that territory of an offence constituted by the conduct but not sentenced for it.

P2para.Text: The conduct constitutes an extradition offence in relation to the category 2 territory if the conditions in subsection (3), (4) or (5) are satisfied.
The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs in the category 2 territory;

the conduct would constitute an offence under the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom punishable with imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 12 months or a greater punishment if it occurred in that part of the United Kingdom;
the conduct is so punishable under the law of the category 2 territory.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs outside the category 2 territory;

in corresponding circumstances equivalent conduct would constitute an extra-territorial offence under the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom punishable with imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 12 months or a greater punishment;
the conduct is so punishable under the law of the category 2 territory.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs outside the category 2 territory;
no part of the conduct occurs in the United Kingdom;
the conduct constitutes, or if committed in the United Kingdom would constitute, an offence mentioned in subsection (6);
the conduct is punishable under the law of the category 2 territory with imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 12 months or a greater punishment.

P2para.Text: After subsection (7) of that section there is inserted—
References in this section to “conduct” (except in the expression “equivalent conduct”) are to the conduct specified in the request for the person’s extradition
In section 138 of that Act (definition of “extradition offence” for the purposes of Part 2 of the Act: person sentenced for offence) for subsections (1) to (5) there is substituted—
This section sets out whether a person’s conduct constitutes an “extradition offence” for the purposes of this Part in a case where the person—

P3para.Text: has been convicted, in the category 2 territory to which extradition is requested, of an offence constituted by the conduct, and
has been sentenced for the offence.

P2para.Text: The conduct constitutes an extradition offence in relation to the category 2 territory if the conditions in subsection (3), (4) or (5) are satisfied.
The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs in the category 2 territory;

the conduct would constitute an offence under the law of the relevant part of the United Kingdom punishable with imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 12 months or a greater punishment if it occurred in that part of the United Kingdom;
a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 4 months or a greater punishment has been imposed in the category 2 territory in respect of the conduct.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs outside the category 2 territory;
in corresponding circumstances equivalent conduct would constitute an extra-territorial offence under the relevant part of the United Kingdom punishable as mentioned in subsection (3)(b);
a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 4 months or a greater punishment has been imposed in the category 2 territory in respect of the conduct.

P2para.Text: The conditions in this subsection are that—

P3para.Text: the conduct occurs outside the category 2 territory;
no part of the conduct occurs in the United Kingdom;
the conduct constitutes, or if committed in the United Kingdom would constitute, an offence mentioned in subsection (6);
a sentence of imprisonment or another form of detention for a term of 4 months or a greater punishment has been imposed in the category 2 territory in respect of the conduct.

P2para.Text: After subsection (7) of that section there is inserted—
References in this section to “conduct” (except in the expression “equivalent conduct”) are to the conduct specified in the request for the person’s extradition

P1group.Title: Proceedings on deferred warrant or request etc

P2para.Text: An extradition claim made in respect of a person is disposed of in the person’s favour if—

P1group.Title: Non-UK extradition: transit through the United Kingdom

P1para.Text: After section 189 of the Extradition Act 2003 there is inserted—

Pblock.Title: Non-UK extradition: transit through the United Kingdom

P1group.Title: Facilitating transit through the United Kingdom

P2para.Text: The relevant UK authority may issue a transit certificate in relation to the non-UK extradition of a person if that authority has been requested to facilitate the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition.
If the relevant UK authority issues a transit certificate in relation to the non-UK extradition of a person, an authorised officer may do any or all of the following—

P3para.Text: escort the person from, or to, any means of transport used for the purposes of the extradition;
take the person into custody to facilitate the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition;
search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to cause physical injury to that person or any other person;

in a case where the person has been taken into custody under paragraph (b), search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to escape from custody.

P2para.Text: An authorised officer searching a person in the exercise of a power conferred by subsection (2)(c) or (d) may seize any item found if the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that the person searched might use the item—

P3para.Text: to cause physical injury to that person or any other person; or
in a case where the person has been taken into custody, to escape from custody.

P2para.Text: If no request is made under subsection (1) in relation to the non-UK extradition of a person, or if such a request is made but a transit certificate is not issued, that does not—

P3para.Text: prevent the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition; or
affect the powers which an authorised officer has (otherwise than under this section) in relation to the person while in the United Kingdom.

P1group.Title: Unscheduled arrival in the United Kingdom

P2para.Text: This section applies in a case where—

P3para.Text: a person is being extradited,
the extradition is a non-UK extradition, and
the person makes an unscheduled arrival in the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: An authorised officer may do any or all of the following—

P3para.Text: take the person into custody to facilitate the transit of the person through the United Kingdom for the purposes of the extradition;
search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to cause physical injury to that person or any other person;

in a case where the person has been taken into custody under paragraph (a), search the person, and any item in the possession of the person, for any item which the person might use to escape from custody.

P2para.Text: Any power conferred by subsection (2) may be exercised—

P3para.Text: upon the unscheduled arrival, or
at any later time when the person is still in the United Kingdom after the unscheduled arrival.

P2para.Text: A person taken into custody under this section may be kept in custody until the expiry of the period of 72 hours beginning with the time when the person is taken (or first taken) into custody under this section.

But if a transit certificate is issued under section 189A in respect of the non-UK extradition of the person, the person must not be kept in custody under this section after the issue of the certificate.
Subsection (5) does not prevent the person from being taken into custody under section 189A.

An authorised officer searching a person in the exercise of a power conferred by subsection (2)(b) or (c) may seize any item found if the officer has reasonable grounds for believing that the person searched might use the item—

P3para.Text: to cause physical injury to that person or any other person; or
in a case where the person has been taken into custody, to escape from custody.

P1group.Title: Exercise of the extradition transit powers

P2para.Text: The extradition transit powers include power to use reasonable force when necessary.
An authorised officer may not, when exercising a relevant search power, require a person to remove any clothing other than an outer coat, jacket, headgear or gloves.
Any item seized from a person in the exercise of a relevant search power may be retained while the person is in transit through the United Kingdom.
The Secretary of State must issue a code of practice in connection with—

P3para.Text: the exercise of extradition transit powers;
the retention, use and return of anything seized under a relevant search power.

P2para.Text: If the Secretary of State proposes to issue a code of practice under this section the Secretary of State must—

P3para.Text: publish a draft of the code;
consider any representations made to the Secretary of State about the draft;
if the Secretary of State thinks it appropriate, modify the draft in the light of any such representations.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State must lay the code before Parliament.
After doing so the Secretary of State may bring the code into operation by order.

The Secretary of State may revise the whole or any part of a code issued under this section and issue the code as revised; and subsections (2) to (4) apply to such a revised code as they apply to the original code.
A failure by an authorised officer to comply with a provision of a code issued under this section does not of itself make the authorised officer liable to criminal or civil proceedings.
A code issued under this section is admissible in evidence in any proceedings and must be taken into account by a court in determining any question to which it appears to the court to be relevant.
If the Secretary of State publishes a draft code of practice in connection with a matter specified in subsection (1) before the date on which this section comes into force—

P3para.Text: the draft is as effective as one published under subsection (2) on or after that date;
representations made to the Secretary of State about the draft before that date are as effective as such representations made after that date;
modifications made by the Secretary of State to the draft in the light of any such representations before that date are as effective as any such modifications made on or after that date.

P2para.Text: An “authorised officer” is—

P3para.Text: a constable, or
a person who is of a description specified by the Secretary of State by order.

P2para.Text: A National Crime Agency officer, prison officer, or any other person who has the powers of a constable (but is not a constable)—

P3para.Text: does not have the extradition transit powers by virtue of having the powers of a constable; and
accordingly, has the extradition transit powers only if the person is of a description specified under subsection (1)(b).

P2para.Text: These expressions have the meanings given—

Para.Text: “extradition transit powers” means the powers under—
section 189A (except the power to issue transit certificates), and
section 189B;
“foreign territory” means a territory outside the United Kingdom;
“non-UK extradition” means extradition from one foreign territory to another foreign territory;
“relevant search power” means a power of search under—
section 189A(2)(c) or (d), or
section 189B(2)(b) or (c);
“relevant UK authority” means—
the National Crime Agency (in the case of a non-UK extradition to a category 1 territory), or
the Secretary of State (in any other case).

P2para.Text: A reference to the transit of a person through the United Kingdom is a reference to the person arriving in, being in, and departing from the United Kingdom (whether or not the person travels within the United Kingdom between arrival and departure).
This section applies for the purposes of section 189A to 189D (and this section).

P1group.Title: Extradition to a territory that is party to an international Convention

P1para.Text: For section 193 of the Extradition Act 2003 there is substituted—

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by order—

P3para.Text: designate an international Convention to which the United Kingdom is a party, and
specify conduct to which the Convention applies.

P2para.Text: If the Secretary of State believes, in respect of a request for a person’s extradition, that—

P3para.Text: the request is for extradition to a territory that is a party to a Convention designated under subsection (1)(a),
the territory is not a category 1 territory or a category 2 territory, and
the conduct specified in the request is conduct specified under subsection (1)(b),

P2para.Text: the Secretary of State may certify that the conditions in paragraphs (a) to (c) are satisfied in relation to the extradition of the person.
If the Secretary of State issues a certificate under subsection (2) this Act applies in respect of the person’s extradition to the territory as if the territory were a category 2 territory.
As applied by subsection (3), this Act has effect as if—

P3para.Text: the conduct that constituted an extradition offence for the purposes of Part 2 were the conduct specified under subsection (1)(b).

P2para.Text: A certificate under subsection (3) in relation to a person is conclusive evidence that the conditions in paragraphs (a) to (c) of subsection (2) are satisfied in relation to the person’s extradition.

P1group.Title: Electronic transmission of European arrest warrant etc

P3para.Text: for “subsection (1), a” there is substituted “subsection (1)—
a
at the end there is inserted—
information contained in the warrant is treated as being received by the designated authority in a form in which it is intelligible if the authority receives—

Pblock.Title: Time spent in custody awaiting extradition to the United Kingdom

P1group.Title: Discount on sentence for time spent in custody awaiting extradition: England and Wales

P1para.Text: In section 49 of the Prison Act 1952 (persons unlawfully at large), after subsection (3) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: Where—

P3para.Text: a person is extradited to the United Kingdom from a category 1 territory for the purpose of serving a term of imprisonment or another form of detention mentioned in subsection (2) of this section, and
the person was for any time kept in custody in that territory with a view to the extradition (and not also for any other reason),

P2para.Text: the Secretary of State shall exercise the power under that subsection to direct that account shall be taken of that time in calculating the period for which the person is liable to be detained.
In subsection (3A) of this section “category 1 territory” means a territory designated under the Extradition Act 2003 for the purposes of Part 1 of that Act.

P1group.Title: Discount on sentence for time spent in custody awaiting extradition: Scotland

P2para.Text: Section 210 of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (consideration of time spent in custody) is amended as follows.

P2para.Text: After subsection (1) there is inserted—
Subsection (1B) applies where—

P3para.Text: a court is passing a sentence of imprisonment or detention on a person for an offence, and

P2para.Text: The court shall specify—

P3para.Text: the period of time spent in custody awaiting extradition, and

After subsection (2) there is inserted—
In this section, “category 1 territory” means a territory designated under the Extradition Act 2003 for the purposes of Part 1 of that Act.

P1group.Title: Discount on sentence for time spent in custody awaiting extradition: Northern Ireland

P2para.Text: The Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 is amended as follows.
In section 2 (trial of summary offences), in subsection (3)(a) for “22” there is substituted “22A”.
After section 22 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Low-value shoplifting to be a summary offence

P2para.Text: Low-value shoplifting is triable only summarily.

But where a person accused of low-value shoplifting is aged 18 or over, and appears or is brought before the court before the summary trial of the offence begins, the court must give the person the opportunity of electing to be tried by the Crown Court for the offence and, if the person elects to be so tried—

P3para.Text: subsection (1) does not apply, and
the court must send the person to the Crown Court for trial for the offence.

P2para.Text: “Low-value shoplifting” means an offence under section 1 of the Theft Act 1968 in circumstances where—

P3para.Text: the value of the stolen goods does not exceed £200,
the goods were being offered for sale in a shop or any other premises, stall, vehicle or place from which there is carried on a trade or business, and
at the time of the offence, the person accused of low-value shoplifting was, or was purporting to be, a customer or potential customer of the person offering the goods for sale.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (3)(a)—

P3para.Text: the value of the stolen goods is the price at which they were being offered for sale at the time of the offence, and
where the accused is charged on the same occasion with two or more offences of low-value shoplifting, the reference to the
value involved has effect as if it were a reference to the aggregate of the values involved.

P2para.Text: A person guilty of low-value shoplifting is liable on summary conviction to—

P3para.Text: imprisonment for a period not exceeding 51 weeks (or 6 months, if the offence was committed before the commencement of section 281(4) and (5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003),
a fine, or
both.

P2para.Text: A person convicted of low-value shoplifting by a magistrates’ court may not appeal to the Crown Court against the conviction on the ground that the convicting court was mistaken as to whether the offence was one of low-value shoplifting.
For the purposes of this section, any reference to low-value shoplifting includes aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of low-value shoplifting.
In section 143 (power to alter sums specified in certain provisions)—

P3para.Text: after subsection (2)(a) there is inserted—
section 22A(3)(a) above;
the word “or” after paragraph (a) of subsection (3) is omitted;
after subsection (3)(a) there is inserted—
in relation to section 22A(3)(a) above, the date of the coming into force of that section; or

P2para.Text: The Criminal Attempts Act 1981 is amended as follows—

P3para.Text: in section 1 (attempting to commit an offence) after subsection (4) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: This section also applies to low-value shoplifting (which is defined in, and is triable only summarily by virtue of, section 22A of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980).

P3para.Text: in section 4 (trial and penalties) in paragraph (c) of subsection (1), after “either way,” there is inserted “or is low-value shoplifting (which is defined in, and is triable only summarily by virtue of, section 22A of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980),”.

P2para.Text: Any reference in the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 to an “indictable offence” has effect as if it included a reference to low-value shoplifting (as defined in section 22A(3) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980).
In section 84 of the Armed Forces Act 2006 (definitions), after subsection (2) there is inserted—
In subsection (2)(a), the reference to an “indictable offence” has effect as if it included a reference to low-value shoplifting (as defined in section 22A(3) of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980).
The amendments made by this section have effect in relation to—

P3para.Text: low-value shoplifting (which is defined in section 22A(3) of the 1980 Act) committed on or after the day on which this section comes into force, and
low-value shoplifting committed before that day in respect of which proceedings have not yet been instituted.

P1group.Title: Protection arrangements for persons at risk

P2para.Text: The Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 is amended as follows.
In section 82 (protection of persons involved in investigations or proceedings)—

P3para.Text: in the heading, for “of persons involved in investigations or proceedings” there is substituted “arrangements for persons at risk”;

in subsection (1), for the words from “a person” to “United Kingdom” there is substituted “any person if he reasonably believes that the person’s safety is at risk in view of the criminal conduct or possible criminal conduct of another person”;
after subsection (5) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: In subsection (1), “criminal conduct” means conduct which constitutes an offence in England and Wales or Scotland, or would do if it occurred there.

Nothing in this section prevents a protection provider from making arrangements under this section for the protection of a person where non-statutory arrangements have already been made in respect of that person.

P3para.Text: subsection (6) is repealed.

P2para.Text: Sections 91 and 92 are repealed.

Schedule 5 is repealed.

P1group.Title: Surcharges: imprisonment in default and remission of fines

P2para.Text: In section 82 of the Magistrates’ Courts Act 1980 (restriction on power to impose imprisonment for default), after subsection (1) there is inserted—
Subsection (1)(c) above does not apply in relation to a surcharge ordered to be paid under section 161A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003.
In section 85 of that Act (power to remit fine), after subsection (3) there is inserted—
Where—

P3para.Text: the court remits the whole or part of the fine, and
the offender was ordered under section 161A of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 to pay a surcharge the amount of which was set by reference to the amount of the fine,

P2para.Text: the court shall determine how much the surcharge would have been if the fine had not included the amount remitted, and remit the balance of the surcharge.
In section 165 of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (remission of fines), after subsection (4) there is inserted—
Where—

P3para.Text: under this section the court remits the whole or part of a fine, and
the offender was ordered under section 161A to pay a surcharge the amount of which was set by reference to the amount of the fine,

P2para.Text: the court must determine how much the surcharge would have been if the fine had not included the amount remitted, and remit the balance of the surcharge.
Subsections (2) and (3) apply in any case where the fine, or part of it, is remitted on or after the day on which this section comes into force.

In prescribing a fee under an enactment specified in subsection (2), the Lord Chancellor may with the consent of the Treasury prescribe a fee of an amount which is intended to exceed the cost of anything in respect of which the fee is charged.
The enactments are—

P3para.Text: section 92 of the Courts Act 2003 (Senior Courts, county courts and magistrates’ courts fees);
section 54 of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (Court of Protection fees);
section 58(4)(b) of that Act (Public Guardian fees);
section 42 of the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007 (tribunal fees).

P2para.Text: Before prescribing a fee by virtue of subsection (1) under an enactment specified in subsection (2)(a), (b) or (d), the Lord Chancellor must have regard to—

P3para.Text: the financial position of the courts and tribunals for which the Lord Chancellor is responsible, including in particular any costs incurred by those courts and tribunals that are not being met by current fee income, and
the competitiveness of the legal services market.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of subsection (3)(a), the courts and tribunals for which the Lord Chancellor is responsible are the courts listed in section 1(1) of the Courts Act 2003 and the tribunals listed in section 39(1) of the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007.
A fee prescribed by virtue of subsection (1) under section 58(4)(b) of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 must be used to finance the efficient and effective discharge of functions of the Public Guardian.
A fee prescribed by virtue of subsection (1) under any other enactment specified in subsection (2) must be used to finance an efficient and effective system of courts and tribunals.
A statutory instrument—

P3para.Text: containing an order or regulations under an enactment specified in subsection (2), and
setting a fee in excess of the cost of anything in respect of which the fee is charged,

P2para.Text: may not be made unless a draft of the instrument has been laid before both Houses of Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House.
But subsection (7) does not apply if the statutory instrument only adjusts a fee to reflect changes in the value of money.

P1para.Text: This Act may be cited as the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act 2013.

P2para.Text: This Schedule applies where—

P3para.Text: a judge has power to remand a person under section 8(5),
a justice of the peace is required to remand a person under section 8(6), or
a court has power to remand a person under section 9(8).

P2para.Text: A reference in the following paragraphs of this Schedule to a judge is to be read as including a justice of the peace.

P1group.Title: Remand in custody or on bail

P2para.Text: The judge or the court may remand the person—

P3para.Text: in custody, or
on bail.

P2para.Text: But a person aged under 18 may not be remanded in custody unless paragraph 6 applies.

A reference in this Schedule to remanding a person in custody is a reference to committing the person to custody to be brought before the court at the end of the period of remand or at whatever earlier time the court may require.
The judge or the court may remand the person on bail—

P3para.Text: by taking from the person a recognizance, with or without sureties, conditioned as provided in paragraph 3, or
by fixing the amount of the recognizances with a view to their being taken subsequently and, in the meantime, committing the person to custody as mentioned in sub-paragraph (2).

P2para.Text: Where a person is brought before the court after remand, the court may further remand the person.
Where a person is remanded on bail, the judge or the court may direct that the person’s recognizance be conditioned for his or her appearance—

P3para.Text: before the court at the end of the period of remand, or
at every time and place to which during the course of the proceedings the hearing may from time to time be adjourned.

P2para.Text: Where a recognizance is conditioned for a person’s appearance as mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(b), the fixing of a time for the person next to appear is to be treated as a remand.
Nothing in this paragraph affects the power of the court at any subsequent hearing to remand the person afresh.
The judge or the court may not remand a person for a period exceeding 8 clear days unless—

P3para.Text: paragraph 5 or 6 applies, or
the person is remanded on bail and both that person and the person who applied for the injunction consent to a longer period.

P2para.Text: Where the judge or the court has power to remand a person in custody, the person may be committed to the custody of a constable if the remand is for a period not exceeding 3 clear days.

P1group.Title: Remand for medical examination and report

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: the judge or the court has reason to think that a medical report will be needed, and
the judge or the court remands the person in order to enable a medical examination to take place and a report to be made.

P2para.Text: If (in the case of a person aged 18 or over) the person is remanded in custody, the adjournment may not be for more than 3 weeks at a time.
If the person is remanded on bail, the adjournment may not be for more than 4 weeks at a time.
If the judge or the court—

P3para.Text: is satisfied, on the written or oral evidence of a registered medical practitioner, that there is reason to suspect that the person is suffering from mental disorder, and
is of the opinion that it would be impracticable for a report on the person’s mental condition to be made if he or she were remanded on bail,

P2para.Text: the judge or the court may remand the person to a hospital or registered establishment specified by the judge or the court for such a report to be made.
In sub-paragraph (1)—

Para.Text: “hospital” has the meaning given by section 145(1) of the Mental Health Act 1983;
“mental disorder” has the meaning given by section 1 of that Act (reading subsection (2B) of that section as if it included a reference to sub-paragraph (1) above);
“registered establishment” has the meaning given by 34(1) of that Act.

P2para.Text: Subsections (4) to (10) of section 35 of the Mental Health Act 1983 apply for the purposes of sub-paragraph (1) with any necessary modifications (in particular, with references to the accused person being read as references to the person mentioned in that sub-paragraph, and references to the court being read as references to the judge or the court).
If the court is satisfied that a person who has been remanded is unable by reason of illness or accident to appear or be brought before the court at the
end of the period of remand, the court may further remand the person in his or her absence.
The power in sub-paragraph (1) may, in the case of a person who was remanded on bail, be exercised by enlarging the person’s recognizance and those of any sureties for the person to a later time.

Where a person remanded on bail is bound to appear before the court at any time and the court has no power to remand the person under sub-paragraph (1), the court may (in the person’s absence) enlarge the person’s recognizance and those of any sureties for the person to a later time.
The enlargement of the person’s recognizance is to be treated as a further remand.
Paragraph 4(1) (limit of remand) does not apply to the exercise of the powers conferred by this paragraph.

P1para.Text: Where under paragraph 2(3)(b) the court fixes the amount in which the principal and the sureties, if any, are to be bound, the recognizance may afterwards be taken by a person prescribed by rules of court, with the same consequences as if it had been entered into before the court.

P1group.Title: Requirements imposed on remand on bail

P1para.Text: The court may when remanding a person on bail under this Schedule require the person to comply, before release on bail or later, with any requirements that appear to the court to be necessary to secure that the person does not interfere with witnesses or otherwise obstruct the course of justice.

TitleBlock.Title: Breach of injunctions: powers of court in respect of under-18s

P1group.Title: Power to make supervision order or detention order

P2para.Text: A youth court, if satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that a person aged under 18 is in breach of a provision of an injunction under section 1 to which he or she is subject, may make in respect of the person—

P3para.Text: a supervision order (see Part 2 of this Schedule), or
a detention order (see Part 3 of this Schedule).

P2para.Text: An order under sub-paragraph (1) may be made only on the application of the person who applied for the injunction.
A person making an application for an order under sub-paragraph (1) must before doing so—

P3para.Text: consult any youth offending team specified under section 2(1) or, if a youth offending team is not specified under that subsection, the local youth offending team within the meaning of section 14;
inform any other body or individual the applicant thinks appropriate.

P2para.Text: In considering whether and how to exercise its powers under this paragraph, the court must consider any representations made by the youth offending team referred to in sub-paragraph (3)(a).
A detention order may not be made under sub-paragraph (1) in respect of a person aged under 14.
The court may not make a detention order under sub-paragraph (1) unless it is satisfied that, in view of the severity or extent of the breach, no other power available to the court is appropriate.
A supervision order is an order imposing on the person in respect of whom it is made (“the defaulter”) one or more of the following requirements—

P3para.Text: a supervision requirement (see paragraph 3);
an activity requirement (see paragraph 4);
a curfew requirement (see paragraph 5).

P2para.Text: Before making a supervision order the court must obtain and consider information about the defaulter’s family circumstances and the likely effect of a supervision order on those circumstances.
Before making a supervision order imposing two or more requirements, the court must consider their compatibility with each other.
The court must ensure, as far as practicable, that requirements imposed by a supervision order are such as to avoid—

P3para.Text: any conflict with the defaulter’s religious beliefs;
any interference with the times, if any, at which the defaulter normally works or attends school or any other educational establishment;
any conflict with the requirements of any other court order or injunction to which the defaulter may be subject.

P2para.Text: A supervision order must for the purposes of this Schedule specify a maximum period for the operation of any requirement contained in the order.
The period specified under sub-paragraph (5) may not exceed 6 months (not counting the day on which the order is made).
A supervision order must for the purposes of this Schedule specify—

P3para.Text: the youth offending team in whose area it appears to the court that the respondent will live during the period specified under sub-paragraph (5), or
if it appears to the court that the defaulter will live in more than one such area, whichever of the relevant youth offending teams the court decides.

P2para.Text: In this Schedule “supervision requirement”, in relation to a supervision order, means a requirement that the defaulter attend appointments with—

P3para.Text: the responsible officer (see paragraph 7), or
another person decided by the responsible officer,

P2para.Text: at whatever times and places the responsible officer instructs.
The appointments must be within the period for the time being specified in the order under paragraph 2(5).

In this Schedule “activity requirement”, in relation to a supervision order, means a requirement that the defaulter do any or all of the following within the period for the time being specified in the order under paragraph 2(5)—

P3para.Text: participate, on however many days are specified in the order, in activities at a place or places specified in it;
participate in an activity or activities specified in the order on however many days are specified in it;
participate in one or more residential exercises for a continuous period or periods comprising however many days are specified in the order;
in accordance with sub-paragraphs (8) to (10), engage in activities in accordance with instructions of the responsible officer on however many days are specified in the order.

P2para.Text: The aggregate number of days specified in a supervision order in relation to an activity requirement must not be less than 12 or more than 24.

A requirement referred to in sub-paragraph (1)(a) operates to require the defaulter, in accordance with instructions given by the responsible officer, on the number of days specified in the order in relation to the requirement—

P3para.Text: to present himself or herself at a place specified in the order to a person of a description specified in it;
on each day, to comply with instructions given by, or under the authority of, the person in charge of the place.

P2para.Text: A requirement referred to in sub-paragraph (1)(b) operates to require the defaulter, in accordance with instructions given by the responsible officer, on the number of days specified in the order in relation to the requirement—

P3para.Text: to participate in an activity specified in the order;
on each day, to comply with instructions given by, or under the authority of, the person in charge of the activity.

P2para.Text: Where the order includes a requirement referred to in sub-paragraph (1)(c) to participate in a residential exercise, it must specify either—

P3para.Text: a place, or
an activity,

P2para.Text: in relation to the exercise.

A requirement under sub-paragraph (1)(c) to participate in a residential exercise in relation to which a place is specified under sub-paragraph (5) operates to require the defaulter, in accordance with instructions given by the responsible officer—

P3para.Text: to present himself or herself at the beginning of the period specified in the order in relation to the exercise, at the place specified in it, to a person of a description specified in the instructions;
to live there for that period;
during that period to comply with instructions given by, or under the authority of, the person in charge of the place.

P2para.Text: A requirement under sub-paragraph (1)(c) to participate in a residential exercise in relation to which an activity is specified under sub-paragraph (5) operates to require the defaulter, in accordance with instructions given by the responsible officer—

P3para.Text: to participate, for the period specified in the order in relation to the exercise, in the activity specified in it;
during that period to comply with instructions given by, or under the authority of, the person in charge of the activity.

P2para.Text: Subject to sub-paragraph (9), instructions under sub-paragraph (1)(d) relating to any particular day must require the defaulter to do either of the following—

P3para.Text: to present himself or herself to a person of a description specified in the instructions at a place specified in them;
to participate in an activity specified in the instructions.

P2para.Text: The instructions operate to require the defaulter, on that day or while participating in that activity, to comply with instructions given by, or under the authority of, the person in charge of the place or activity.

If the supervision order so provides, instructions under sub-paragraph (1)(d) may require the defaulter to participate in a residential exercise for a period comprising not more than seven days, and for that purpose—

P3para.Text: to present himself or herself at the beginning of that period to a person of a description specified in the instructions at a place specified in them, and to live there for that period, or
to participate for that period in an activity specified in the instructions.

P2para.Text: Instructions of the kind mentioned in sub-paragraph (9)—

P3para.Text: may not be given except with the consent of a parent or guardian of the defaulter;

operate to require the defaulter, during the period specified under that sub-paragraph, to comply with instructions given by, or under the authority of, the person in charge of the place or activity specified under paragraph (a) or (b) of that sub-paragraph.

P2para.Text: Instructions given by, or under the authority of, a person in charge of a place under sub-paragraph (3)(b), (6)(c), (8) or (10)(b) may require the defaulter to engage in activities otherwise than at that place.

Where a supervision order contains an activity requirement, the court may, on the application of the original applicant or the defaulter, amend the order by substituting for a number of days, place, activity, period or description of persons specified in the order a new number of days, place, activity, period or description (subject, in the case of a number of days, to sub-paragraph (2)).
A court may include an activity requirement in a supervision order or vary an activity requirement under sub-paragraph (12) only if—

P3para.Text: it has consulted the youth offending team that is to be, or is, specified in the order,
it is satisfied that it is feasible to secure compliance with the requirement, or the requirement as varied,

it is satisfied that provision for the defaulter to participate in the activities proposed can be made under the arrangements for persons to participate in those activities which exist in the area of the youth offending team that is to be, or is, specified in the order, and

in a case where the requirement, or the requirement as varied, would involve the co-operation of a person other than the defaulter and the responsible officer, that person consents to its inclusion or variation.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (10) “guardian” has the same meaning as in the Children and Young Persons Act 1933.
But where a local authority has parental responsibility (within the meaning given by section 3 of the Children Act 1989) for a defaulter who—

P3para.Text: is in the authority’s care, or
is provided with accommodation by the authority in the exercise of social services functions (within the meaning given by section 1A of the Local Authority Social Services Act 1970),

P2para.Text: the reference to “guardian” in sub-paragraph (10) is to be read as a reference to that authority.
In this Schedule “curfew requirement”, in relation to a supervision order, means a requirement that the defaulter remain at a place specified in the order for the periods specified in it.
A supervision order imposing a curfew requirement may specify different places or different periods for different days.
The periods specified under sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: must be within the period for the time being specified in the order under paragraph 2(5);
may not amount to less than 2 or more than 8 hours in any day.

P2para.Text: Before specifying a place under sub-paragraph (1), the court making the order must obtain and consider information about the place proposed to be specified (including information as to the attitude of persons likely to be affected by the enforced presence there of the defaulter).
Where a supervision order contains a curfew requirement, the court may, on the application of the original applicant or the defaulter, amend the order by—

P3para.Text: substituting new periods for the periods specified in the order under this paragraph (subject to sub-paragraph (3));
substituting a new place for the place specified in the order under this paragraph (subject to sub-paragraph (4)).

P2para.Text: A supervision order containing a curfew requirement may also contain a requirement (an “electronic monitoring requirement”) for securing the electronic monitoring of compliance with the curfew requirement during a period—

P3para.Text: specified in the order, or
determined by the responsible officer in accordance with the order.

P2para.Text: In the case referred to in sub-paragraph (1)(b), the responsible officer must, before the beginning of the period when the electronic monitoring requirement is to take effect, notify—

P3para.Text: the defaulter,
the person responsible for the monitoring, and
any person within sub-paragraph (3)(b),

P2para.Text: of the time when that period is to begin.
Where—

P3para.Text: it is proposed to include an electronic monitoring requirement in a supervision order, but
there is a person (other than the defaulter) without whose co-operation it will not be practicable to secure that the monitoring takes place,

P2para.Text: the requirement may not be included in the order without that person’s consent.
A supervision order imposing an electronic monitoring requirement must include provision for making a person responsible for the monitoring.
An electronic monitoring requirement may not be included in a supervision order unless the court making the order—

P3para.Text: has been notified by the youth offending team for the time being specified in the order that arrangements for electronic monitoring are available in the area that includes the place the court proposes to specify in the order for the purposes of the curfew requirement, and
is satisfied that the necessary provision can be made under the arrangements currently available.

P2para.Text: Where a supervision order contains an electronic monitoring requirement, the court may, on the application of the original applicant or the defaulter, amend the order by substituting a new period for the period specified in the order under this paragraph.
Sub-paragraph (3) applies in relation to the variation of an electronic monitoring requirement under sub-paragraph (6) as it applies in relation to the inclusion of a requirement.
For the purposes of this Part of this Schedule, the “responsible officer”, in relation to a supervision order, means—

P3para.Text: in a case where the order imposes a curfew requirement and an electronic monitoring requirement, but does not impose an activity or supervision requirement, the person who under paragraph 6(4) is responsible for the electronic monitoring;

in any other case, the member of the youth offending team for the time being specified in the order who is for the time being responsible for discharging the functions conferred by this Schedule on the responsible officer.

P2para.Text: Where a supervision order has been made, it is the duty of the responsible officer—

P3para.Text: to make any arrangements that are necessary in connection with the requirements contained in the order;
to promote the defaulter’s compliance with those requirements.

P2para.Text: The responsible officer must ensure, so far as practicable, that any instructions given by the officer under a supervision order are such as to avoid the things referred to in paragraph 2(4).
A defaulter in respect of whom a supervision order is made must—

P3para.Text: keep in touch with the responsible officer, in accordance with any instructions given by the responsible officer from time to time;
notify the responsible officer of any change of address.

P2para.Text: These obligations have effect as requirements of the order.

The court may, on the application of the original applicant, amend a supervision order by substituting a new period for the one specified in the order for the time being under paragraph 2(5) (subject to paragraph 2(6)).
A court amending a supervision order under sub-paragraph (1) may make whatever other amendments to the order the court considers appropriate in relation to a requirement imposed by the order.

P1group.Title: Amendment on change of area of residence

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where, on an application made in relation to a supervision order by the original applicant or the defaulter, the court is satisfied that the defaulter proposes to live, or is living, in the area of a youth offending team other than the team for the time being specified in the order.

If the application is made by the defaulter, the court may amend the order by substituting for the youth offending team specified in the order the youth offending team for the area referred to in sub-paragraph (1) (or, if there is more than one youth offending team for that area, whichever of them the court decides).
If the application is made by the original applicant, the court must amend the order in the way mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) (subject to sub-paragraph (5)).

Where a court amends the supervision order under sub-paragraph (2) or (3) but the order contains a requirement that, in the opinion of the court, cannot reasonably be complied with if the defaulter lives in the area referred to in sub-paragraph (1), the court must also amend the order by—

P3para.Text: removing that requirement, or
substituting for that requirement a new requirement that can reasonably be complied with if the defaulter lives in that area.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (3) does not require a court to amend the supervision order if in its opinion sub-paragraph (4) would produce an inappropriate result.
The original applicant must consult the youth offending team for the time being specified in the order before making an application under sub-paragraph (1).
The original applicant or the defaulter may apply to a youth court—

P3para.Text: to revoke a supervision order;
to amend a supervision order by removing a requirement from it.

P2para.Text: If it appears to the court to be in the interests of justice to do so, having regard to circumstances that have arisen since the supervision order was made, the court may grant an application under sub-paragraph (1) and revoke or amend the order accordingly.
The circumstances referred to in sub-paragraph (2) include the conduct of the defaulter.
If an application under this paragraph is dismissed, the party by which the dismissed application was made may make no further application under this paragraph without—

P3para.Text: the consent of the court, or
the agreement of the other party.

P2para.Text: The original applicant must consult the youth offending team for the time being specified in the supervision order before making an application under sub-paragraph (1).

P1para.Text: If the responsible officer considers that the defaulter has complied with all the requirements of the supervision order, the officer must inform the original applicant.

P2para.Text: If the responsible officer considers that the defaulter has failed to comply with a requirement of the supervision order, the officer must inform the original applicant.
On being informed under sub-paragraph (1) the original applicant may apply to a youth court.
Before making an application under sub-paragraph (2) the original applicant must—

P3para.Text: consult the youth offending team for the time being specified in the order;
inform any other body or individual the original applicant thinks appropriate.

P2para.Text: If on an application under sub-paragraph (2) the court is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the defaulter has without reasonable excuse failed to comply with a requirement of the supervision order, the court may—

P3para.Text: revoke the supervision order and make a new one;
revoke the order and make a detention order (see Part 3 of this Schedule).

P2para.Text: The powers in sub-paragraph (4)—

P3para.Text: may not be exercised after the defaulter reaches the age of 18;
are in addition to any other power of the court in relation to the breach of the supervision order.

P2para.Text: The court must consider any representations made by the youth offending team for the time being specified in the order before exercising its powers under this paragraph.
A court that makes a supervision order must straight away provide a copy of the order to—

P3para.Text: the defaulter;
the youth offending team for the time being specified in the order.

P2para.Text: Where a supervision order is made, the original applicant must straight away provide a copy of so much of the order as is relevant—

P3para.Text: in a case where the order includes an activity requirement specifying a place under paragraph 4(1)(a), to the person in charge of that place;
in a case where the order includes an activity requirement specifying an activity under paragraph 4(1)(b), to the person in charge of that activity;

in a case where the order includes an activity requirement specifying a residential exercise under paragraph 4(1)(c), to the person in charge of the place or activity specified under paragraph 4(5) in relation to that residential exercise;
in a case where the order contains an electronic monitoring requirement, to—

P4para.Text: any person who by virtue of paragraph 6(4) will be responsible for the electronic monitoring, and
any person without whose consent that requirement could not have been included in the order.

P2para.Text: A court that revokes or amends a supervision order must straight away provide a copy of the revoking order, or of the order as amended, to—

P3para.Text: the defaulter;
the youth offending team for the time being specified in the order.

P2para.Text: Where—

P3para.Text: a copy of a supervision order (or part of a supervision order) has been given to a person under sub-paragraph (2) by virtue of a requirement contained in the order, and
the order is revoked, or amended in respect of that requirement,

P2para.Text: the original applicant must straight away give a copy of the revoking order, or of so much of the order as amended as is relevant, to that person.

A detention order is an order that the person in respect of whom it is made (“the defaulter”) be detained for a period specified in the order in whatever youth detention accommodation the Secretary of State decides.
The period specified under sub-paragraph (1) may not exceed the period of 3 months (not counting the day on which the order is made).
In sub-paragraph (1) “youth detention accommodation” means—

P3para.Text: a secure training centre;
a young offender institution;
secure accommodation, as defined by section 23(12) of the Children and Young Persons Act 1969.

P2para.Text: The function of the Secretary of State under sub-paragraph (1) is exercisable concurrently with the Youth Justice Board.
A person detained under a detention order is in legal custody.
Where a detention order is made, the original applicant or the defaulter may apply to a youth court to revoke it.

If it appears to the court to be in the interests of justice to do so, having regard to circumstances that have arisen since the detention order was made, the court may grant an application under sub-paragraph (1) and revoke the order accordingly.
The circumstances referred to in sub-paragraph (2) include the conduct of the defaulter.
If an application under this paragraph is dismissed, the party by which the dismissed application was made may make no further application under this paragraph without—

P3para.Text: the consent of the court, or
the agreement of the other party.
