P2para.Text: A person making an application under this paragraph in relation to a detention order made under paragraph 1 must before doing so consult any youth offending team specified in the injunction under section 2(1) or, if none is specified, the local youth offending team within the meaning of section 14.

A person making an application under this paragraph in relation to a detention order made under paragraph 12(4)(b) must before doing so consult the youth offending team for the time being specified in the relevant supervision order.

TitleBlock.Title: Schedule to be inserted as Schedule 2A to the Housing Act 1985
Absolute ground for possession for anti-social behaviour: serious offences

P1para.Text: Murder.
Manslaughter.
Kidnapping.
False imprisonment.
An offence under any of the following sections of the Offences against the Person Act 1861—

P3para.Text: section 4 (soliciting murder),
section 16 (threats to kill),
section 18 (wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm),
section 20 (malicious wounding),
section 21 (attempting to choke, suffocate or strangle in order to commit or assist in committing an indictable offence),
section 22 (using chloroform etc. to commit or assist in the committing of any indictable offence),
section 23 (maliciously administering poison etc. so as to endanger life or inflict grievous bodily harm),
section 24 (maliciously administering poison etc. with intent to injure, aggrieve or annoy any other person),
section 27 (abandoning or exposing children whereby life is endangered or health permanently injured),
section 28 (causing bodily injury by explosives),
section 29 (using explosives etc. with intent to do grievous bodily harm),
section 30 (placing explosives with intent to do bodily injury),
section 31 (setting spring guns etc. with intent to do grievous bodily harm),
section 38 (assault with intent to resist arrest),
section 47 (assault occasioning actual bodily harm).

P1para.Text: An offence under any of the following sections of the Explosive Substances Act 1883—

P3para.Text: section 2 (causing explosion likely to endanger life or property),
section 3 (attempt to cause explosion, or making or keeping explosive with intent to endanger life or property),
section 4 (making or possession of explosive under suspicious circumstances).

P1para.Text: An offence under section 1 of the Infant Life (Preservation) Act 1929 (child destruction).
An offence under section 1 of the Children and Young Persons Act 1933 (cruelty to children).
An offence under section 1 of the Infanticide Act 1938 (infanticide).
An offence under any of the following sections of the Public Order Act 1986—

P3para.Text: section 1 (riot),
section 2 (violent disorder),
section 3 (affray).

P1para.Text: An offence under either of the following sections of the Protection from Harassment Act 1997—

P3para.Text: section 4 (putting people in fear of violence),
section 4A (stalking involving fear of violence or serious alarm or distress).

P1para.Text: An offence under any of the following provisions of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998—

P3para.Text: section 29 (racially or religiously aggravated assaults),
section 31(1)(a) or (b) (racially or religiously aggravated offences under section 4 or 4A of the Public Order Act 1986),
section 32 (racially or religiously aggravated harassment etc.).

P1para.Text: An offence under either of the following sections of the Female Genital Mutilation Act 2003—

P3para.Text: section 1 (female genital mutilation),
section 2 (assisting a girl to mutilate her own genitalia).

P1para.Text: An offence under section 5 of the Domestic Violence, Crime and Victims Act 2004 (causing or allowing the death of a child or vulnerable adult).
An offence under section 33A of the Sexual Offences Act 1956 (keeping a brothel used for prostitution).
An offence under section 1 of the Protection of Children Act 1978 (indecent photographs of children).
An offence under section 160 of the Criminal Justice Act 1988 (possession of indecent photograph of a child).
An indictable offence under Part 1 of the Sexual Offences Act 2003 (sexual offences).
An offence under either of the following sections of the Prevention of Crime Act 1953—

P3para.Text: section 1 (prohibition of the carrying of offensive weapons without lawful authority or reasonable excuse),
section 1A (threatening with offensive weapon in public).

P1para.Text: An offence under any of the following provisions of the Firearms Act 1968—

P3para.Text: section 16 (possession of firearm with intent to endanger life),
section 16A (possession of firearm with intent to cause fear of violence),
section 17(1) (use of firearm to resist arrest),
section 17(2) (possession of firearm at time of committing or being arrested for offence specified in Schedule 1 to the Act of 1968),
section 18 (carrying a firearm with criminal intent),
section 19 (carrying a firearm in a public place),
section 20 (trespassing with firearm),
section 21 (possession of firearms by persons previously convicted of crime).

P1para.Text: An offence under either of the following sections of the Criminal Justice Act 1988—

P3para.Text: section 139 (having article with blade or point in public place),
section 139AA (threatening with article with blade or point or offensive weapon).

P1para.Text: An offence under any of the following sections of the Theft Act 1968—

P3para.Text: section 8 (robbery or assault with intent to rob),
section 9 (burglary),
section 10 (aggravated burglary).

P1para.Text: An offence under section 1 of the Criminal Damage Act 1971 (destroying or damaging property).
An offence under section 30 of the Crime and Disorder Act 1998 (racially or religiously aggravated criminal damage).
An offence under section 35 of the Offences against the Person Act 1861 (injuring persons by furious driving).
An offence under section 12A of the Theft Act 1968 (aggravated vehicle-taking involving an accident which caused the death of any person).
An offence under any of the following sections of the Road Traffic Act 1988—

P3para.Text: section 1 (causing death by dangerous driving),
section 1A (causing serious injury by dangerous driving),
section 3A (causing death by careless driving when under influence of drink or drugs).

P1para.Text: An offence under any of the following provisions of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971—

P3para.Text: section 4 (restriction of production and supply of controlled drugs),
section 5(3) (possession of controlled drugs with intent to supply),
section 8(a) or (b) (occupiers etc. of premises to be punishable for permitting unlawful production or supply etc. of controlled drugs there).

P1para.Text: An offence under section 6 of that Act (restrictions of cultivation of cannabis plant) where the cultivation is for profit and the whole or a substantial part of the dwelling-house concerned is used for the cultivation.

P2para.Text: An offence of attempting or conspiring the commission of an offence specified or described in this Schedule.

An offence under Part 2 of the Serious Crime Act 2007 (encouraging or assisting) where the offence (or one of the offences) which the person in question intends or believes would be committed is an offence specified or described in this Schedule.
An offence of aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of an offence specified or described in this Schedule.

P1para.Text: Where this Schedule refers to offences which are offences under the law of England and Wales and another country or territory, the reference is to be read as limited to the offences so far as they are offences under the law of England and Wales.

Part.Title: Making and revising review procedures etc

P2para.Text: In making and revising the review procedures, the relevant bodies in a local government area must consult the local policing body for the relevant police area.
The “relevant police area” is the police area which consists of, or includes, the local government area.

P1group.Title: Consultation: local providers of social housing

P1para.Text: In making and revising the review procedures, the relevant bodies in a local government area must consult such local providers of social housing as they consider appropriate.
The review procedures must include provision about what is to happen where an applicant is dissatisfied with the way in which the relevant bodies have—

P3para.Text: dealt with an application for an ASB case review, or
carried out an ASB case review.

P1group.Title: Assessment and revision of review procedures

P1para.Text: The review procedures must include provision about—

P3para.Text: the assessment of the effectiveness of those procedures, and
the revision of those procedures.

Part.Title: Inclusion of local providers of social housing among relevant bodies

P2para.Text: The responsible authorities in a local government area must make arrangements (“co-option arrangements”) for the inclusion of local providers of social housing among the relevant bodies in that area.
In this paragraph “responsible authorities” means—

P3para.Text: in relation to a local government area in England—

P4para.Text: the relevant district council or the unitary authority,
the chief officer of police for the police area which that local government area is within, and
each clinical commissioning group established under section 14V of the National Health Service Act 2006 whose area is wholly or partly within that local government area;

P3para.Text: in relation to a local government area in Wales—

P4para.Text: the council for the area,
the chief officer of police for the police area which that local government area is within, and
each Local Health Board whose area is wholly or partly within that local government area.

P1group.Title: Consultation and co-operation: local providers of social housing

P2para.Text: The relevant bodies in a local government area must consult such local providers of social housing as they consider appropriate in carrying out ASB case reviews.
The local providers of social housing must co-operate with the relevant bodies in the local government area in any matters specified by the relevant bodies that concern ASB case reviews.
The relevant bodies in a local government area may request any person to disclose information for a purpose connected with the carrying out of an ASB case review.

If such a request is made to a person that exercises public functions, and that person possesses the requested information in connection with the exercise of such functions, the person must (subject to sub-paragraph (4)) comply with the request.
If such a request is made to a person who is not required by sub-paragraph (2) to disclose the requested information, the person may (subject to sub-paragraph (4)) comply with the request.
This paragraph does not require or authorise—

P3para.Text: a disclosure, in contravention of any provisions of the Data Protection Act 1998, of personal data which are not exempt from those provisions, or
a disclosure which is prohibited by Part 1 of the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000.

P2para.Text: Subject to that, a disclosure under this paragraph does not breach—

P3para.Text: any obligation of confidence owed by the person making the disclosure, or
any other restriction on the disclosure of information (however imposed).

P1group.Title: Joint review procedures or co-option arrangements

P2para.Text: The relevant bodies in two or more local government areas—

P3para.Text: may jointly make review procedures applicable to those areas;
must secure that such jointly-made review procedures are in place if co-option arrangements applicable to those areas have been jointly made under sub-paragraph (2).

P2para.Text: The responsible authorities in two or more local government areas—

P3para.Text: may jointly make co-option arrangements applicable to those areas;
must secure that such jointly-made co-option arrangements are in place if review procedures applicable to those areas have been jointly made under sub-paragraph (1).

P2para.Text: In a case where review procedures or co-option arrangements are made jointly in accordance with this paragraph, a reference to any of the following in section 96, section 97 or this Schedule is to be read accordingly—

P3para.Text: the relevant bodies (in the case of review procedures) or the responsible authorities (in the case of co-option arrangements);
the local government area or the relevant police area (in either case).

P1group.Title: Different review procedures or co-option arrangements for different parts of an area etc

P2para.Text: Review procedures may make different provision in relation to different parts of a local government area.
Review procedures or co-option arrangements made jointly in accordance with paragraph 8 may make different provision in relation to—

P3para.Text: different local government areas to which the procedures or arrangements are applicable, or
different parts of such areas.

TitleBlock.Title: Amendments of Part 2 of the Sexual Offences Act 2003

P1para.Text: Part 2 of the Sexual Offences Act 2003 (notification and orders) is amended as set out in this Schedule.
After section 103 there is inserted—

Pblock.Title: Sexual harm prevention orders (England and Wales)

P1group.Title: Sexual harm prevention orders: applications and grounds

P2para.Text: A court may make an order under this section (a “sexual harm prevention order”) in respect of a person (“the defendant”) where subsection (2) or (3) applies to the defendant.
This subsection applies to the defendant where—

P3para.Text: the court deals with the defendant in respect of—

P4para.Text: an offence listed in Schedule 3 or 5, or
a finding that the defendant is not guilty of an offence listed in Schedule 3 or 5 by reason of insanity, or
a finding that the defendant is under a disability and has done the act charged against the defendant in respect of an offence listed in Schedule 3 or 5,

P3para.Text: and
the court is satisfied that it is necessary to make a sexual harm prevention order, for the purpose of—

P4para.Text: protecting the public or any particular members of the public from sexual harm from the defendant, or
protecting children or vulnerable adults generally, or any particular children or vulnerable adults, from sexual harm from the defendant outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies to the defendant where—

P3para.Text: an application under subsection (4) has been made in respect of the defendant and it is proved on the application that the defendant is a qualifying offender, and
the court is satisfied that the defendant’s behaviour since the appropriate date makes it necessary to make a sexual harm prevention order, for the purpose of—

P4para.Text: protecting the public or any particular members of the public from sexual harm from the defendant, or
protecting children or vulnerable adults generally, or any particular children or vulnerable adults, from sexual harm from the defendant outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: A chief officer of police or the Director General of the National Crime Agency (“the Director General”) may by complaint to a magistrates’ court apply for a sexual harm prevention order in respect of a person if it appears to the chief officer or the Director General that—

P3para.Text: the person is a qualifying offender, and
the person has since the appropriate date acted in such a way as to give reasonable cause to believe that it is necessary for such an order to be made.

P2para.Text: A chief officer of police may make an application under subsection (4) only in respect of a person—

P3para.Text: who resides in the chief officer’s police area, or
who the chief officer believes is in that area or is intending to come to it.

P2para.Text: An application under subsection (4) may be made to any magistrates’ court whose commission area includes—

P3para.Text: any part of a relevant police area, or
any place where it is alleged that the person acted in a way mentioned in subsection (4)(b).

P2para.Text: The Director General must as soon as practicable notify the chief officer of police for a relevant police area of any application that the Director has made under subsection (4).
In this section “relevant police area” means—

P3para.Text: where the applicant is a chief officer of police, the officer’s police area;
where the applicant is the Director General—

P4para.Text: the police area where the person in question resides, or
a police area which the Director General believes the person is in or is intending to come to.

P2para.Text: In section 103A—

Para.Text: “appropriate date”, in relation to a qualifying offender, means the date or (as the case may be) the first date on which the offender was convicted, found or cautioned as mentioned in subsection (2) or (3) below;
“child” means a person under 18;
“the public” means the public in the United Kingdom;
“sexual harm” from a person means physical or psychological harm caused—
by the person committing one or more offences listed in Schedule 3, or

(in the context of harm outside the United Kingdom) by the person doing, outside the United Kingdom, anything which would constitute an offence listed in Schedule 3 if done in any part of the United Kingdom;
“qualifying offender” means a person within subsection (2) or (3) below;

“vulnerable adult” means a person aged 18 or over whose ability to protect himself or herself from physical or psychological harm is significantly impaired through physical or mental disability or illness, through old age or otherwise.

P2para.Text: A person is within this subsection if, whether before or after the commencement of this Part, the person—

P3para.Text: has been convicted of an offence listed in Schedule 3 (other than at paragraph 60) or in Schedule 5,
has been found not guilty of such an offence by reason of insanity,
has been found to be under a disability and to have done the act charged against him in respect of such an offence, or
has been cautioned in respect of such an offence.

P2para.Text: A person is within this subsection if, under the law in force in a country outside the United Kingdom and whether before or after the commencement of this Part—

P3para.Text: the person has been convicted of a relevant offence (whether or not the person has been punished for it),
a court exercising jurisdiction under that law has made in respect of a relevant offence a finding equivalent to a finding that the person is not guilty by reason of insanity,
such a court has made in respect of a relevant offence a finding equivalent to a finding that the person is under a disability and did the act charged against the person in respect of the offence, or
the person has been cautioned in respect of a relevant offence.

P2para.Text: In subsection (3), “relevant offence” means an act which—

P3para.Text: constituted an offence under the law in force in the country concerned, and
would have constituted an offence listed in Schedule 3 (other than at paragraph 60) or in Schedule 5 if it had been done in any part of the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: For this purpose an act punishable under the law in force in a country outside the United Kingdom constitutes an offence under that law, however it is described in that law.
For the purposes of section 103A, acts, behaviour, convictions and findings include those occurring before the commencement of this Part.

Subject to subsection (7), on an application under section 103A(4) the condition in subsection (4)(b) above (where relevant) is to be taken as met unless, not later than rules of court may provide, the defendant serves on the applicant a notice—

P3para.Text: stating that, on the facts as alleged with respect to the act concerned, the condition is not in the defendant’s opinion met,
showing the grounds for that opinion, and
requiring the applicant to prove that the condition is met.

P2para.Text: The court, if it thinks fit, may permit the defendant to require the applicant to prove that the condition is met without service of a notice under subsection (6).
Subsection (9) applies for the purposes of section 103A and this section.
In construing any reference to an offence listed in Schedule 3, any condition subject to which an offence is so listed that relates—

P3para.Text: to the way in which the defendant is dealt with in respect of an offence so listed or a relevant finding (as defined by section 132(9)), or
to the age of any person,

P2para.Text: is to be disregarded.
A sexual harm prevention order prohibits the defendant from doing anything described in the order.
Subject to section 103D(1), a prohibition contained in a sexual harm prevention order has effect—

P3para.Text: for a fixed period, specified in the order, of at least 5 years, or
until further order.

P2para.Text: A sexual harm prevention order—

P3para.Text: may specify that some of its prohibitions have effect until further order and some for a fixed period;
may specify different periods for different prohibitions.

P2para.Text: The only prohibitions that may be included in a sexual harm prevention order are those necessary for the purpose of—

P3para.Text: protecting the public or any particular members of the public from sexual harm from the defendant, or
protecting children or vulnerable adults generally, or any particular children or vulnerable adults, from sexual harm from the defendant outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: In subsection (4) “the public”, “sexual harm”, “child” and “vulnerable adult” each has the meaning given in section 103B(1).
Where a court makes a sexual harm prevention order in relation to a person who is already subject to such an order (whether made by that court or another), the earlier order ceases to have effect.
A prohibition on foreign travel contained in a sexual harm prevention order must be for a fixed period of not more than 5 years.
A “prohibition on foreign travel” means—

P3para.Text: a prohibition on travelling to any country outside the United Kingdom named or described in the order,
a prohibition on travelling to any country outside the United Kingdom other than a country named or described in the order, or
a prohibition on travelling to any country outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) does not prevent a prohibition on foreign travel from being extended for a further period (of no more than 5 years each time) under section 103E.

A sexual harm prevention order that contains a prohibition within subsection (2)(c) must require the defendant to surrender all of the defendant’s passports at a police station specified in the order—

P3para.Text: on or before the date when the prohibition takes effect, or
within a period specified in the order.

P2para.Text: Any passports surrendered must be returned as soon as reasonably practicable after the person ceases to be subject to a sexual harm prevention order containing a prohibition within subsection (2)(c) (unless the person is subject to an equivalent prohibition under another order).
Subsection (5) does not apply in relation to—

P3para.Text: a passport issued by or on behalf of the authorities of a country outside the United Kingdom if the passport has been returned to those authorities;
a passport issued by or on behalf of an international organisation if the passport has been returned to that organisation.

P2para.Text: In this section “passport” means—

P3para.Text: a United Kingdom passport within the meaning of the Immigration Act 1971;
a passport issued by or on behalf of the authorities of a country outside the United Kingdom, or by or on behalf of an international organisation;
a document that can be used (in some or all circumstances) instead of a passport.

P2para.Text: A person within subsection (2) may apply to the appropriate court for an order varying, renewing or discharging a sexual harm prevention order.
The persons are—

P3para.Text: the defendant;
the chief officer of police for the area in which the defendant resides;
a chief officer of police who believes that the defendant is in, or is intending to come to, that officer’s police area;
where the order was made on an application by a chief officer of police under section 103A(4), that officer.

P2para.Text: An application under subsection (1) may be made—

P3para.Text: where the appropriate court is the Crown Court, in accordance with rules of court;
in any other case, by complaint.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsections (5) and (6), on the application the court, after hearing the person making the application and (if they wish to be heard) the other persons mentioned in subsection (2), may make any order, varying, renewing or discharging the sexual harm prevention order, that the court considers appropriate.
An order may be renewed, or varied so as to impose additional prohibitions on the defendant, only if it is necessary to do so for the purpose of—

P3para.Text: protecting the public or any particular members of the public from sexual harm from the defendant, or
protecting children or vulnerable adults generally, or any particular children or vulnerable adults, from sexual harm from the defendant outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: Any renewed or varied order may contain only such prohibitions as are necessary for this purpose.
The court must not discharge an order before the end of 5 years beginning with the day on which the order was made, without the consent of the defendant and—

P3para.Text: where the application is made by a chief officer of police, that chief officer, or
in any other case, the chief officer of police for the area in which the defendant resides.

P2para.Text: Subsection (6) does not apply to an order containing a prohibition on foreign travel and no other prohibitions.
In this section “the appropriate court” means—

P3para.Text: where the Crown Court or the Court of Appeal made the sexual harm prevention order, the Crown Court;

where a magistrates’ court made the order, that court, a magistrates’ court for the area in which the defendant resides or, where the application is made by a chief officer of police, any magistrates’ court whose commission area includes any part of the chief officer’s police area;

where a youth court made the order, that court, a youth court for the area in which the defendant resides or, where the application is made by a chief officer of police, any youth court whose commission area includes any part of the chief officer’s police area.

P2para.Text: This section applies where an application under section 103A(4) (“the main application”) has not been determined.
An application for an order under this section (“an interim sexual harm prevention order”)—

P3para.Text: may be made by the complaint by which the main application is made, or
if the main application has been made, may be made by the person who has made that application, by complaint to the court to which that application has been made.

P2para.Text: The court may, if it considers it just to do so, make an interim sexual harm prevention order, prohibiting the defendant from doing anything described in the order.
Such an order—

P3para.Text: has effect only for a fixed period, specified in the order;
ceases to have effect, if it has not already done so, on the determination of the main application.

P2para.Text: The applicant or the defendant may by complaint apply to the court that made the interim sexual harm prevention order for the order to be varied, renewed or discharged.

P1group.Title: SHPOs and interim SHPOs: notification requirements

P2para.Text: Where—

P3para.Text: a sexual harm prevention order is made in respect of a defendant who was a relevant offender immediately before the making of the order, and
the defendant would (apart from this subsection) cease to be subject to the notification requirements of this Part while the order (as renewed from time to time) has effect,

P2para.Text: the defendant remains subject to the notification requirements.
Where a sexual harm prevention order is made in respect of a defendant who was not a relevant offender immediately before the making of the order—

P3para.Text: the order causes the defendant to become subject to the notification requirements of this Part from the making of the order until the order (as renewed from time to time) ceases to have effect, and
this Part applies to the defendant, subject to the modification set out in subsection (3).

P2para.Text: The “relevant date” is the date of service of the order.

Subsections (1) to (3) apply to an interim sexual harm prevention order as if references to a sexual harm prevention order were references to an interim sexual harm prevention order, and with the omission of “(as renewed from time to time)” in both places.
Where—

P3para.Text: a sexual harm prevention order is in effect in relation to a relevant sex offender (within the meaning of section 88A), and
by virtue of section 88F or 88G the relevant sex offender ceases to be subject to the notification requirements of this Part,

P2para.Text: the sexual harm prevention order ceases to have effect.

On an application for a sexual harm prevention order made by a chief officer of police, the court must make a notification order in respect of the defendant (either in addition to or instead of a sexual harm prevention order) if—

P3para.Text: the applicant invites the court to do so, and
it is proved that the conditions in section 97(2) to (4) are met.

P2para.Text: On an application for an interim sexual harm prevention order made by a chief officer of police, the court may, if it considers it just to do so, make an interim notification order (either in addition to or instead of an interim sexual harm prevention order).
A defendant may appeal against the making of a sexual harm prevention order—

P3para.Text: where the order was made by virtue of section 103A(2)(a)(i), as if the order were a sentence passed on the defendant for the offence;
where the order was made by virtue of section 103A(2)(a)(ii) or (iii), as if the defendant had been convicted of the offence and the order were a sentence passed on the defendant for that offence;
where the order was made on an application under section 103A(4), to the Crown Court.

P2para.Text: A defendant may appeal to the Crown Court against the making of an interim sexual harm prevention order.
A defendant may appeal against the making of an order under section 103E, or the refusal to make such an order—

P3para.Text: where the application for such an order was made to the Crown Court, to the Court of Appeal;
in any other case, to the Crown Court.

P2para.Text: On an appeal under subsection (1)(c), (2) or (3)(b), the Crown Court may make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to its determination of the appeal, and may also make such incidental or consequential orders as appear to it to be just.

Any order made by the Crown Court on an appeal under subsection (1)(c) or (2) (other than an order directing that an application be re-heard by a magistrates’ court) is for the purposes of section 103E(8) or 103F(5) (respectively) to be treated as if it were an order of the court from which the appeal was brought (and not an order of the Crown Court).

P1group.Title: Offence: breach of SHPO or interim SHPO etc

P2para.Text: A person who, without reasonable excuse, does anything that the person is prohibited from doing by—

P3para.Text: a sexual harm prevention order,
an interim sexual harm prevention order,
a sexual offences prevention order,
an interim sexual offences prevention order, or
a foreign travel order,

P2para.Text: commits an offence.
A person commits an offence if, without reasonable excuse, the person fails to comply with a requirement imposed under section 103D(4).
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or a fine or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 5 years.

P2para.Text: Where a person is convicted of an offence under this section, it is not open to the court by or before which the person is convicted to make, in respect of the offence, an order for conditional discharge.

The Secretary of State must issue guidance to chief officers of police and to the Director General of the National Crime Agency in relation to the exercise by them of their powers with regard to sexual harm prevention orders and interim sexual harm prevention orders.
The Secretary of State may, from time to time, revise the guidance issued under subsection (1).
The Secretary of State must arrange for any guidance issued or revised under this section to be published in such manner as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

P1group.Title: Sexual offences prevention orders and foreign travel orders

P2para.Text: Sections 104 to 122 (sexual offences prevention orders and foreign travel orders) are repealed.
This paragraph extends only to England and Wales.

P1para.Text: Before section 123 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Sexual risk orders: applications, grounds and effect

P2para.Text: A chief officer of police or the Director General of the National Crime Agency (“the Director General”) may by complaint to a magistrates’ court apply for an order under this section (a “sexual risk order”) in respect of a person (“the defendant”) if it appears to the chief officer or the Director General that the following condition is met.

The condition is that the defendant has, whether before or after the commencement of this Part, done an act of a sexual nature as a result of which there is reasonable cause to believe that it is necessary for a sexual risk order to be made.
A chief officer of police may make an application under subsection (1) only in respect of a person—

P3para.Text: who resides in the chief officer’s police area, or
who the chief officer believes is in that area or is intending to come to it.

P2para.Text: An application under subsection (1) may be made to any magistrates’ court whose commission area includes—

P3para.Text: any part of a relevant police area, or
any place where it is alleged that the person acted in a way mentioned in subsection (2).

P2para.Text: The Director General must as soon as practicable notify the chief officer of police for a relevant police area of any application that the Director has made under subsection (1).
On an application under subsection (1), the court may make a sexual risk order if it is satisfied that the defendant has, whether before or
after the commencement of this Part, done an act of a sexual nature as a result of which it is necessary to make such an order for the purpose of—

P3para.Text: protecting the public or any particular members of the public from harm from the defendant, or
protecting children or vulnerable adults generally, or any particular children or vulnerable adults, from harm from the defendant outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: Such an order—

P3para.Text: prohibits the defendant from doing anything described in the order;
has effect for a fixed period (not less than 2 years) specified in the order or until further order.

P2para.Text: A sexual risk order may specify different periods for different prohibitions.
The only prohibitions that may be imposed are those necessary for the purpose of—

P3para.Text: protecting the public or any particular members of the public from harm from the defendant, or
protecting children or vulnerable adults generally, or any particular children or vulnerable adults, from harm from the defendant outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: Where a court makes a sexual risk order in relation to a person who is already subject to such an order (whether made by that court or another), the earlier order ceases to have effect.
In section 122A—

Para.Text: “child” means a person under 18;
“harm” from the defendant means physical or psychological harm caused by the defendant doing an act of a sexual nature;
“the public” means the public in the United Kingdom;

“vulnerable adult” means a person aged 18 or over whose ability to protect himself or herself from physical or psychological harm is significantly impaired through physical or mental disability or illness, through old age or otherwise.

P2para.Text: In that section “relevant police area” means—

P3para.Text: where the applicant is a chief officer of police, the officer’s police area;
where the applicant is the Director General of the National Crime Agency—

P4para.Text: the police area where the person in question resides, or
a police area which the Director General believes the person is in or is intending to come to.

P1group.Title: Sexual risk orders: prohibitions on foreign travel

P2para.Text: A prohibition on foreign travel contained in a sexual risk order must not be for a period of more than 5 years.
A “prohibition on foreign travel” means—

P3para.Text: a prohibition on travelling to any country outside the United Kingdom named or described in the order,
a prohibition on travelling to any country outside the United Kingdom other than a country named or described in the order, or
a prohibition on travelling to any country outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) does not prevent a prohibition on foreign travel from being extended for a further period (of no more than 5 years each time) under section 122D.
A sexual risk order that contains a prohibition within subsection (2)(c) must require the defendant to surrender all of the defendant’s passports at a police station specified in the order—

P3para.Text: on or before the date when the prohibition takes effect, or
within a period specified in the order.

P2para.Text: Any passports surrendered must be returned as soon as reasonably practicable after the person ceases to be subject to a sexual risk order containing such a prohibition (unless the person is subject to an equivalent prohibition under another order).
Subsection (5) does not apply in relation to—

P3para.Text: a passport issued by or on behalf of the authorities of a country outside the United Kingdom if the passport has been returned to those authorities;
a passport issued by or on behalf of an international organisation if the passport has been returned to that organisation.

P2para.Text: In this section “passport” means—

P3para.Text: a United Kingdom passport within the meaning of the Immigration Act 1971;
a passport issued by or on behalf of the authorities of a country outside the United Kingdom, or by or on behalf of an international organisation;
a document that can be used (in some or all circumstances) instead of a passport.

P1group.Title: Sexual risk order: variations, renewals and discharges

P2para.Text: A person within subsection (2) may by complaint to the appropriate court apply for an order varying, renewing or discharging a sexual risk order.
The persons are—

P3para.Text: the defendant;
the chief officer of police for the area in which the defendant resides;
a chief officer of police who believes that the defendant is in, or is intending to come to, that officer’s police area;
where the order was made on an application by a chief officer of police, that officer.

P2para.Text: Subject to subsections (4) and (5), on the application the court, after hearing the person making the application and (if they wish to be heard) the other persons mentioned in subsection (2), may make any order, varying, renewing or discharging the sexual risk order, that the court considers appropriate.
An order may be renewed, or varied so as to impose additional prohibitions on the defendant, only if it is necessary to do so for the purpose of—

P3para.Text: protecting the public or any particular members of the public from harm from the defendant, or
protecting children or vulnerable adults generally, or any particular children or vulnerable adults, from harm from the defendant outside the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: Any renewed or varied order may contain only such prohibitions as are necessary for this purpose.
The court must not discharge an order before the end of 2 years beginning with the day on which the order was made, without the consent of the defendant and—

P3para.Text: where the application is made by a chief officer of police, that chief officer, or
in any other case, the chief officer of police for the area in which the defendant resides.

P2para.Text: Section 122B(1) applies for the purposes of this section.
In this section “the appropriate court” means—

P3para.Text: the court which made the sexual risk order;
a magistrates’ court for the area in which the defendant resides;
where the application is made by a chief officer of police, any magistrates’ court whose commission area includes any part of the officer’s police area.

P2para.Text: This section applies where an application for a sexual risk order (“the main application”) has not been determined.
An application for an order under this section (“an interim sexual risk order”)—

P3para.Text: may be made by the complaint by which the main application is made, or
if the main application has been made, may be made by the person who has made that application, by complaint to the court to which that application has been made.

P2para.Text: The court may, if it considers it just to do so, make an interim sexual risk order, prohibiting the defendant from doing anything described in the order.
Such an order—

P3para.Text: has effect only for a fixed period, specified in the order;
ceases to have effect, if it has not already done so, on the determination of the main application.

P2para.Text: The applicant or the defendant may by complaint apply to the court that made the interim sexual risk order for the order to be varied, renewed or discharged.

P1group.Title: Sexual risk orders and interim sexual risk orders: notification requirements

P2para.Text: A person in respect of whom a court makes—

P3para.Text: a sexual risk order (other than one that replaces an interim sexual risk order), or
an interim sexual risk order,

P2para.Text: must, within the period of 3 days beginning with the date of service of the order, notify to the police the information set out in subsection (2) (unless the person is subject to the notification requirements of this Part on that date).
The information is—

P3para.Text: the person’s name and, where the person uses one or more other names, each of those names;
the person’s home address.

P2para.Text: A person who—

P3para.Text: is subject to a sexual risk order or an interim sexual risk order (but is not subject to the notification requirements of this Part), and
uses a name which has not been notified under this section (or under any other provision of this Part), or changes home address,

P2para.Text: must, within the period of 3 days beginning with the date on which that happens, notify to the police that name or (as the case may be) the new home address.
Sections 87 (method of notification and related matters) and 91 (offences relating to notification) apply for the purposes of this section—

P3para.Text: with references to section 83(1) being read as references to subsection (1) above,
with references to section 84(1) being read as references to subsection (3) above, and
with the omission of section 87(2)(b).

P1group.Title: Sexual risk orders and interim sexual risk orders: appeals

P2para.Text: A defendant may appeal to the Crown Court—

P3para.Text: against the making of a sexual risk order;
against the making of an interim sexual risk order; or
against the making of an order under section 122D, or the refusal to make such an order.

P2para.Text: On any such appeal, the Crown Court may make such orders as may be necessary to give effect to its determination of the appeal, and may also make such incidental or consequential orders as appear to it to be just.

Any order made by the Crown Court on an appeal under subsection (1)(a) or (b) (other than an order directing that an application be re-heard by a magistrates’ court) is for the purposes of section 122D(7) or 122E(5) (respectively) to be treated as if it were an order of the court from which the appeal was brought (and not an order of the Crown Court).

P1group.Title: Offence: breach of sexual risk order or interim sexual risk order etc

P2para.Text: A person who, without reasonable excuse, does anything that the person is prohibited from doing by—

P3para.Text: a sexual risk order,
an interim sexual risk order,
a risk of sexual harm order,
an interim risk of sexual harm order,
an order under section 2 of the Protection of Children and Prevention of Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2005 (risk of sexual harm orders in Scotland), or
an order under section 5 of that Act (interim risk of sexual harm orders in Scotland),

P2para.Text: commits an offence.
A person commits an offence if, without reasonable excuse, the person fails to comply with a requirement imposed under section 122C(4).
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable—

P3para.Text: on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months or a fine or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 5 years.

P2para.Text: Where a person is convicted of an offence under this section, it is not open to the court by or before which the person is convicted to make, in respect of the offence, an order for conditional discharge.

P1group.Title: Effect of conviction etc of an offence under section 122H etc

P2para.Text: This section applies to a person (“the defendant”) who—

P3para.Text: is convicted of an offence mentioned in subsection (2);
is found not guilty of such an offence by reason of insanity;
is found to be under a disability and to have done the act charged against him in respect of such an offence; or
is cautioned in respect of such an offence.

P2para.Text: Those offences are—

P3para.Text: an offence under section 122H or 128 of this Act;

an offence under section 7 of the Protection of Children and Prevention of Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2005 (contravention of risk of sexual harm order or interim risk of sexual harm order in Scotland).

P2para.Text: Where—

P3para.Text: a defendant was a relevant offender immediately before this section applied to the defendant, and
the defendant would (apart from this subsection) cease to be subject to the notification requirements of this Part while the relevant order (as renewed from time to time) has effect,

P2para.Text: the defendant remains subject to the notification requirements.
Where the defendant was not a relevant offender immediately before this section applied to the defendant—

P3para.Text: this section causes the defendant to become subject to the notification requirements of this Part from the time the section first applies to the defendant until the relevant order (as renewed from time to time) ceases to have effect, and
this Part applies to the defendant, subject to the modification set out in subsection (5).

P2para.Text: The “relevant date” is the date on which this section first applies to the defendant.
In this section “relevant order” means—

P3para.Text: where the conviction, finding or caution within subsection (1) is in respect of a breach of a sexual risk order or a risk of sexual harm order, that order;

where the conviction, finding or caution within subsection (1) is in respect of a breach of an interim sexual risk order or an interim risk of sexual harm order, any sexual risk order or risk of sexual harm order made on the hearing of the application to which the interim order relates or, if no such order is made, the interim order.

P2para.Text: In subsection (6) “risk of sexual harm order” and “interim risk of sexual harm order” include orders under sections 2 and 5 (respectively) of the Protection of Children and Prevention of Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2005.

P1group.Title: Sexual risk orders and interim sexual risk orders: guidance

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State must issue guidance to chief officers of police and to the Director General of the National Crime Agency in relation to the exercise by them of their powers with regard to sexual risk orders and interim sexual risk orders.
The Secretary of State may, from time to time, revise the guidance issued under subsection (1).
The Secretary of State must arrange for any guidance issued or revised under this section to be published in such manner as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.
Sections 123 to 129 (risk of sexual harm orders) are repealed.
This paragraph extends only to England and Wales.

P1para.Text: After section 136 there is inserted—

P1group.Title: Application of orders throughout the United Kingdom

P2para.Text: In this section “relevant order” means—

P3para.Text: a sexual harm prevention order;
an interim sexual harm prevention order;
a sexual offences prevention order;
an interim sexual offences prevention order;
a foreign travel order;
a sexual risk order;
an interim sexual risk order;
a risk of sexual harm order;
an interim risk of sexual harm order;
an order under section 2 of the Protection of Children and Prevention of Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2005 (risk of sexual harm orders in Scotland);
an order under section 5 of that Act (interim risk of sexual harm orders in Scotland).

P2para.Text: For the purposes of sections 103I, 113, 122, 122H and 128, prohibitions imposed by a relevant order made in one part of the United Kingdom apply (unless expressly confined to particular localities) throughout that and every other part of the United Kingdom.

P1group.Title: Order ceases to have effect when new order made

P2para.Text: Where a court in England and Wales makes an order listed in the first column of the following Table in relation to a person who is already subject to an order listed opposite it in the second column, the earlier order ceases to have effect (whichever part of the United Kingdom it was made in) unless the court orders otherwise.

tr.td: —risk of sexual harm order; —foreign travel order.

P2para.Text: Where a court in Northern Ireland or Scotland makes an order listed in the first column of the following Table in relation to a person who is already subject to an order or prohibition listed opposite it in the second column, the earlier order or prohibition ceases to have effect (even though it was made or imposed by a court in England and Wales) unless the court orders otherwise.

tr.td: —sexual harm prevention order not containing a prohibition on foreign travel; —in the case of a sexual harm prevention order containing a prohibition on foreign travel, each of its other prohibitions.
—prohibition on foreign travel contained in a sexual harm prevention order.
—sexual risk order not containing a prohibition on foreign travel; —in the case of a sexual risk order containing a prohibition on foreign travel, each of its other prohibitions.

P2para.Text: In this section—

P3para.Text: “court”, in Scotland, includes sheriff;
“risk of sexual harm order” includes an order under section 2 of the Protection of Children and Prevention of Sexual Offences (Scotland) Act 2005.

TitleBlock.Title: Schedule to be inserted as Schedule 4B to the Police Act 1996

P1para.Text: In this Schedule “review body” means the Police Remuneration Review Body.
The Secretary of State shall determine how many members the review body should have and what kinds of experience the members should possess.
Members shall hold and vacate office in accordance with the terms of their appointment.
Members shall adhere to any statement of principles issued by the Secretary of State as to their conduct as members.

P2para.Text: The chair of the review body may resign by giving written notice to the Prime Minister.
Resignation may be either—

P3para.Text: as chair, or
as both chair and member.

P2para.Text: The deputy chair of the review body may resign by giving written notice to the Secretary of State.
Resignation may be either—

P3para.Text: as deputy chair, or
as both deputy chair and member.

P1para.Text: A member other than the chair or deputy chair may resign by giving written notice to the Secretary of State.

P2para.Text: The Prime Minister may by written notice dismiss the chair on the ground that—

P3para.Text: the chair has been adjudged bankrupt, has been made the subject of a debt relief order (under Part 7A of the Insolvency Act 1986) or has made an arrangement with creditors;
in the opinion of the Prime Minister the chair is unable, unfit or unwilling to perform—

P4para.Text: the functions of chair, or
the functions of a member.

P2para.Text: Dismissal may be either—

P3para.Text: as chair, or
as both chair and member (but only if sub-paragraph (1)(a) or (b)(ii) applies).

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State may by written notice dismiss the deputy chair on the ground that—

P3para.Text: the deputy chair has been adjudged bankrupt, has been made the subject of a debt relief order (under Part 7A of the Insolvency Act 1986) or has made an arrangement with creditors;
in the opinion of the Secretary of State the deputy chair is unable, unfit or unwilling to perform—

P4para.Text: the functions of deputy chair, or
the functions of a member.

P2para.Text: Dismissal may be either—

P3para.Text: as deputy chair, or
as both deputy chair and member (but only if sub-paragraph (1)(a) or (b)(ii) applies).

P1para.Text: The Secretary of State may by written notice dismiss a member other than the chair or deputy chair on the ground that—

P3para.Text: the member has been adjudged bankrupt, has been made the subject of a debt relief order (under Part 7A of the Insolvency Act 1986) or has made an arrangement with creditors, or
in the opinion of the Secretary of State the member is unable, unfit or unwilling to perform the functions of a member.

P2para.Text: Subject to sub-paragraph (2), the review body shall determine its own procedure.
The Secretary of State may give directions to the review body as to its procedure, including in particular directions about—

P3para.Text: the persons from whom the review body is to obtain evidence;
the procedure for obtaining evidence.

P2para.Text: The validity of proceedings of the review body is not affected by—

P3para.Text: a vacancy in its membership (including a vacancy in the position of chair);
a defect in a person’s appointment.

P1para.Text: The Secretary of State may give directions to the review body about the matters that it is to consider when making decisions.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State shall consult with the persons and bodies listed in sub-paragraph (2), and any others that the Secretary of State thinks fit, before—

P3para.Text: making or revising a determination under paragraph 2;
issuing or revising a statement of principles under paragraph 4;
giving or revising a direction under paragraph 11(2) or 12.

P2para.Text: The persons and bodies are—

P3para.Text: the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland;
persons whom the Secretary of State considers to represent the views of chief officers of police and of the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland;
persons whom the Secretary of State considers to represent the interests of members of police forces;
persons whom the Secretary of State considers to represent the interests of members of the Police Service of Northern Ireland;
persons whom the Secretary of State considers to represent the views of the persons and bodies who between them maintain the police forces in England and Wales;
the Northern Ireland Policing Board.

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State shall consult with the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland before exercising a power of dismissal under paragraph 8, 9 or 10.

P1para.Text: The Secretary of State shall arrange for the publication of—

P3para.Text: a statement of any determination made under paragraph 2 (and of any revised determination);
any statement of principles issued under paragraph 4 (and any revised statement);
any direction given under paragraph 11(2) or 12 (and any revised direction).

P1para.Text: The Secretary of State or the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland—

P3para.Text: may defray expenses incurred by the review body;
may pay remuneration and allowances to members;
may make payments to or in respect of a member by way of or in connection with—

P4para.Text: a pension;
an allowance or gratuity on retirement or death;

P3para.Text: may pay compensation to a person who ceases to be a member if it seems to the Secretary of State or the Department to be right to do so by reason of special circumstances.

TitleBlock.Title: Powers to seize invalid passports etc

P2para.Text: In this Schedule “examining officer” means—

P3para.Text: a constable,
a person appointed as an immigration officer under paragraph 1 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971, or
a general customs official designated under section 3(1) of the Borders, Citizenship and Immigration Act 2009.

P2para.Text: In this Schedule “travel document” means anything that is, or appears to be, a passport or other document which—

P3para.Text: has been issued by or for Her Majesty’s Government, or the government of another state, and
enables or facilitates travel from one state to another.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this Schedule a travel document is “invalid” if—

P3para.Text: it has been cancelled,
it has expired,
it was not issued by the government or authority by which it purports to have been issued, or
it has undergone an unauthorised alteration.

P2para.Text: In this Schedule “port” means—

P3para.Text: an airport,
a sea port,
a hoverport,
a heliport,
a railway station where passenger trains depart for, or arrive from, places outside the United Kingdom, or
any other place at which a person is able, or attempting, to get on or off any craft, vessel or vehicle in connection with entering or leaving Great Britain or Northern Ireland.

P1group.Title: Powers of search and seizure etc: ports

P2para.Text: An examining officer may exercise any of the powers under this paragraph in the case of a person at a port whom the officer believes to be there in connection with—

P3para.Text: entering or leaving Great Britain or Northern Ireland, or
travelling by air within Great Britain or within Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: The powers are—

P3para.Text: to require the person to hand over all travel documents in his or her possession for inspection by the examining officer;
to search for travel documents and to take possession of any that the officer finds;
to inspect any travel document taken from the person and to retain it while its validity is checked;
(subject to paragraph 4) to retain any travel document taken from the person that the examining officer believes to be invalid.

P2para.Text: The power under sub-paragraph (2)(b) is a power to search—

P3para.Text: the person;
anything that the person has with him or her;
any vehicle in which the examining officer believes the person to have been travelling or to be about to travel.

P2para.Text: An examining officer—

P3para.Text: may stop a person or vehicle for the purposes of exercising a power under this paragraph;
may if necessary use reasonable force for the purpose of exercising a power under this paragraph;
may authorise a person to carry out on the officer’s behalf a search under this paragraph.

P1group.Title: Powers of search and seizure etc: constables

P2para.Text: A constable may exercise any of the powers under this paragraph, at a place that is not a port, in the case of a person whom the constable reasonably believes to be in possession of a passport to which this paragraph applies.
This paragraph applies to a passport if—

P3para.Text: the passport was issued by or for Her Majesty’s Government,

the Secretary of State has cancelled the passport on the basis that the person to whom it was issued has or may have been, or will or may become, involved in activities so undesirable that it is contrary to the public interest for the person to have access to passport facilities, and
the passport is specified in an authorisation issued by the Secretary of State for the use of the powers under this paragraph.

P2para.Text: The powers are—

P3para.Text: to require the person to hand over all travel documents in his or her possession for inspection by the constable;
to search for travel documents and to take possession of any that the constable finds;
to inspect any travel document taken from the person and to retain it while its validity is checked;
(subject to paragraph 4) to retain any travel document taken from the person that the constable believes to be invalid.

P2para.Text: The power under sub-paragraph (3)(b) is a power to search—

P3para.Text: the person;
anything that the person has with him or her;
any vehicle in which the constable believes the person to have been travelling or to be about to travel;
any premises on which the constable is lawfully present.

P2para.Text: A constable—

P3para.Text: may if necessary use reasonable force for the purpose of exercising a power under this paragraph;
may authorise a person to carry out on the constable’s behalf a search under this paragraph.

P1group.Title: Retention or return of documents seized

P2para.Text: If a travel document is retained under paragraph 2(2)(c) or 3(3)(c) while its validity is checked, the checking must be carried out as soon as possible.
If it is established that a travel document taken from a person under paragraph 2 or 3—

P3para.Text: is valid, or
is invalid only because it has expired,

P2para.Text: it must be returned to the person straight away.

A travel document taken from a person under paragraph 2 or 3 must be returned to the person before the end of the period of 7 days beginning with the day on which it was taken, unless during that period it is established that the document is invalid for some reason other than expiry.

A requirement under sub-paragraph (2)(b) or (3) to return an expired travel document does not apply where the officer concerned reasonably believes that the person from whom he or she took the document, or some other person, intends to use it for purposes for which it is no longer valid.
A requirement under sub-paragraph (2) or (3) to return a travel document has effect subject to any provision not in this Schedule under which the document may be lawfully retained.
A person who is required under paragraph 2(2)(a) or 3(3)(a) to hand over all travel documents in the person’s possession commits an offence if he or she fails without reasonable excuse to do so.
A person who intentionally obstructs, or seeks to frustrate, a search under paragraph 2 or 3 commits an offence.
A person guilty of an offence under this paragraph is liable on summary conviction—

P3para.Text: to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months, or
to a fine, which in Scotland or Northern Ireland may not exceed £5,000,

P2para.Text: or to both.

P1para.Text: An examining officer, other than a constable, exercising a power under paragraph 2 has the same powers of arrest without warrant as a constable in relation to an offence under—

P3para.Text: paragraph 6, or
section 4 or 6 of the Identity Documents Act 2010.

P2para.Text: In particular, the code must make provision for consultation with the relevant chief officer of police before designations are made under paragraph 1(1)(b) or (c).

in Scotland, the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Scotland, and
in Northern Ireland, the Chief Constable of the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

P1group.Title: Time limits on examination without detention and on detention

P2para.Text: Schedule 7 to the Terrorism Act 2000 is amended as follows.

This paragraph applies where a person is questioned under paragraph 2 or 3.
After the end of the 1 hour period, the person may not be questioned under either of those paragraphs unless the person is detained under paragraph 6.
If the person is detained under paragraph 6 the person must be released not later than the end of the 6 hour period (unless detained under another power).
In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “the 1 hour period” is the period of 1 hour beginning with the time the person is first questioned under paragraph 2 or 3;
“the 6 hour period” is the period of 6 hours beginning with that time.

P1para.Text: In paragraph 8 of Schedule 7 to the Terrorism Act 2000, after sub-paragraph (3) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: An intimate search of a person may not be carried out under this paragraph.
A strip search of a person may not be carried out under this paragraph unless—

P3para.Text: the person is detained under paragraph 6,
the examining officer has reasonable grounds to suspect that the person is concealing something which may be evidence that the person falls within section 40(1)(b), and
the search is authorised by a senior officer who has not been directly involved in questioning the person.

P2para.Text: “Senior officer” means—

P3para.Text: where the examining officer is a constable, a constable of a higher rank than the examining officer,
where the examining officer is an immigration officer, an immigration officer of a higher grade than the examining officer, and
where the examining officer is a customs officer, a customs officer of a higher grade than the examining officer.

P2para.Text: In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “intimate search” means a search which consists of a physical examination of a person’s body orifices other than the mouth;
“strip search” means a search which is not an intimate search but involves the removal of an article of clothing which—
is being worn wholly or partly on the trunk, and
is being so worn either next to the skin or next to an article of underwear.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where the examining officer is a constable.

P2para.Text: The copy may be retained—

while the examining officer believes that it may be needed for use as evidence in criminal proceedings, or
while the examining officer believes that it may be needed in connection with a decision by the Secretary of State whether to make a deportation order under the Immigration Act 1971.

P2para.Text: In Schedule 8, after Part 1 there is inserted—

The review officer may authorise a person’s continued detention under Schedule 7 only if satisfied that it is necessary for the purposes of exercising a power under paragraph 2 or 3 of that Schedule.
If on a review under this paragraph the review officer does not authorise a person’s continued detention, the person must be released (unless detained under another power).

P1para.Text: In section 38 of the Prison Act (Northern Ireland) 1953 (arrest, etc, of persons unlawfully at large), in subsection (4), for “the last foregoing sub-section” there is substituted “subsection (2)”.

P3para.Text: absence of prosecution decision, or
forum,

Section 21 of that Act (human rights) is amended as follows.
For the heading there is substituted “Person unlawfully at large: human rights”.
In subsection (1) the words “11 or” are omitted.

P1para.Text: In section 26 of that Act (appeal against extradition order: category 1 territory), in subsection (4), for “Notice of an appeal” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal”.

In section 28 of that Act (appeal against discharge at extradition hearing: category 1 territory), in subsection (5), for “Notice of an appeal” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal”.
In section 35 of that Act (extradition where there is no appeal), after subsection (4) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: If the day referred to in paragraph (a) of subsection (4) is earlier than the earliest day on which, by reason of an order under section 36A or 36B, the extradition order may be carried out (“the postponed date”), that paragraph has effect as if it referred instead to the postponed date.

P1para.Text: In section 36 of that Act (extradition following appeal), after subsection (3) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: If the day referred to in paragraph (a) of subsection (3) is earlier than the earliest day on which, by reason of an order under section 36A or 36B, the extradition order may be carried out (“the postponed date”), that paragraph has effect as if it referred instead to the postponed date.

P1para.Text: In section 66 of that Act (supplementary provision for the purposes of sections 64 and 65), in subsection (1), for “(2)” there is substituted “(1A)”.
In section 103 of that Act (appeal where case sent to Secretary of State), in subsection (9), for “Notice of an appeal” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal”.

In section 105 of that Act (appeal against discharge at extradition hearing: category 2 territory), in subsection (5), for “Notice of an appeal” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal”.

P2para.Text: Section 108 of that Act (appeal against extradition order: category 2 territory) is amended as follows.
In subsection (4), for the words before “is 14 days” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal under this section must be given—

P3para.Text: in accordance with rules of court, and
subject to subsections (5) and (7A), before the end of the permitted period, which

P2para.Text: In subsection (5)—

P3para.Text: for “But notice of an appeal” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal”
after “if it is an” there is inserted “application for leave to”.

P2para.Text: In subsection (6), for the words before “before the person is extradited” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal on human rights grounds given after the end of the permitted period must be given”.
In subsection (7)—

P3para.Text: for “notice of an appeal” there is substituted “notice of application for leave to appeal”;
for “consider the appeal” there is substituted “grant leave”;
for “to consider the appeal” there is substituted “for the appeal to be heard”.

P2para.Text: In subsection (8), for ““appeal on human rights grounds” means an appeal” there is substituted ““to appeal on human rights grounds” means to appeal”.

P1para.Text: In section 110 of that Act (appeal against discharge by Secretary of State), in subsection (5), for “Notice of an appeal” there is substituted “Notice of application for leave to appeal”.
In section 117 of that Act (extradition where there is no appeal), in subsection (2), for the words after “28 days” there is substituted “starting with—

P3para.Text: the day on which the Secretary of State makes the extradition order, or
if an order is made under section 118A or 118B, the earliest day on which the extradition order may be carried out.

P1para.Text: In section 118 of that Act (extradition following appeal), after subsection (2) there is inserted—

P2para.Text: But if the day referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (3) is earlier than the earliest day on which, by reason of an order under section 118A or 118B, the extradition order may be carried out (“the postponed date”), the required period is 28 days beginning with the postponed date.

P1para.Text: In section 137 (definition of extradition offence for the purposes of Part 2 of the Act: person not sentenced for offence) subsection (9) is repealed.
In section 138 (definition of extradition offence for the purposes of Part 2 of the Act: person sentenced for offence) subsection (9) is repealed.

P2para.Text: Section 197 of that Act (custody) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1), at the end there is inserted—
This is subject to the power to order the temporary transfer of a person under section 21B.
After subsection (6) there is inserted—
An order for a person’s temporary transfer under section 21B is sufficient authority for an appropriate person—

P3para.Text: to receive him;
to keep him in custody until he is transferred in accordance with the order;
to convey him to and from the territory to which he is to be transferred;
on his return from that territory, to keep him in custody until he is brought back to the institution to which he was committed.

P2para.Text: Section 204 of that Act (warrant issued by category 1 territory: transmission by electronic means) is amended as follows.
In subsections (1)(c) and (2)(c), for “a qualifying form” there is substituted “a form in which it is intelligible and which is capable of being used for subsequent reference”.
In subsection (6)—

P3para.Text: at the end of paragraph (a) there is inserted “and”;
paragraph (c) and the word “and” before it are omitted.

P2para.Text: Section 216 of that Act (interpretative provisions) is amended as set out in sub-paragraphs (2) and (3).
After subsection (10) there is inserted—
Human Rights Convention” has the meaning given to “the Convention” by section 21(1) of the Human Rights Act 1998.
After subsection (12) there is inserted—
Refugee Convention” means the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees done at Geneva on 28 July 1951 and the Protocol to the Convention.
The following provisions of that Act are repealed in consequence of sub-paragraphs (2) and (3)—

P3para.Text: the definition of “the Refugee Convention” in section 40(4);
section 70(2A);
section 153D(3).

Part.Title: Amendments consequential on establishment of Police Service of Scotland

P2para.Text: Schedule 8 to the Terrorism Act 2000 (detention) is amended as follows.
In paragraph 20B(10), for paragraph (b) of the definition of “a specified chief officer of police” there is substituted—

P3para.Text: the chief constable of the Police Service of Scotland, where—

P4para.Text: the person who provided the material, or from whom it was taken, resides in Scotland, or
the chief constable believes that the person is in, or is intending to come to, Scotland.

P2para.Text: In paragraph 20J—

P3para.Text: for paragraphs (d) and (e) of the definition of “police force” there is substituted—
the Police Service of Scotland;
the Scottish Police Authority;
in the second of the three definitions of “responsible chief officer of police”, for the words after “the chief constable of” there is substituted “the Police Service of Scotland”.

P2para.Text: In section 18D of the Counter-Terrorism Act 2008 (use of retained material), in subsection (2) for “the Scottish Police Services Authority” there is substituted “the Scottish Police Authority”.
In section 18E(1) of that Act (interpretation of sections 18 to 18E), for paragraph (d) of the definition of “police force” there is substituted—

P3para.Text: the Police Service of Scotland;
